reviewText: An atmospheric, sometimes scary Lovecraft-esque adventure game with stunning graphics.\n\nDetective games are hard to do, since it is difficult to make the player feel like it is THEY who are performing the deductions/making the inferences. LA Noire and Murdered: Soul Suspect both failed to give the player this feeling, but The Vanishing of Ethan Carter IMO manages to nail it. The crime scene chronology" mechanic is fantastic
date: elegant yet requires the use of your brain to make inferences from the clues. Having to return the scene of the crime back to how it was when the deceased was killed is also a nice touch and makes sense for a "psychic detective."\n\nThe graphics are frankly gorgeous
recommended: although unfortunately the performance isn't as stable as it should be.\n\nThe plot is good (although the ending can feel like a bit of an M. Night Shyamalan cop-out-twist-bordering-on-a-deus-ex-machina)
hoursPlayed: the music is very appropriate and fitting
voteText:
and I enjoyed my time with the game.

The big drawback is the game's length; it can easily be finished in less than four hours.

I'd advise buying the game if you love horror games

then I'd say they've proven their concept with flying colors.

PROS:
+ Best investigation mechanics I've yet encountered in a detective game
+ Atmospheric
+ Incredible graphics

CONS:

Overall: Fans of horror and/or adventure games should certainly consider purchasing this game."

reviewText:
Čaute steamáčky a steamáci.

Zase raz píšem kratšiu recenziu o jednej kratšej hre.
Táto ... hmm behacio-klikacia adventúra, ma chytila za srdce a dokonca si vravím že ju musím odporučiť aj okoliu. Nielenže Má dokonalú grafiku, ale príbehovo vôbec nezaostáva. A čo je na tom naozaj MEGA. Nedá sa predpovedať ako skončí. Teda možno sa dá, ale ja som to nečakal. Fakt silný príbeh s ešte silnejším podaním skrz unreal engin, ktorý dokonale podtrháva atmosféru zaujme všetkých hráčov. Samotné jazerá i lesy ma tak okúzlili, že som troška nemal záujem o ten dej, iba sa prechádzať po lokalite. Mapa o sebe je rozhľahlá natoľko že od prvého tunela po posledný cíp pobrežia pri záverečnom dome to trvá skoro 10 minút reálneho času, ak postava celý čas beží, a neskracuje si cestu výťahom. TO je dosť veľká mapa, a nepotrebuje načítavanie, plynule prechádate skrz jej lokality. Škoda že nie je rozsiahlejšia, bral by som, ak by sa po tých horách dalo skutočne prejsť. To miesto pôsobí magicky očarujúco.
Samotná hrateľnosť ale nie je pre začiatočníkov. Je to naozaj náročná hra, pretože neobsahuje žiadne vodítka, kde čo máte hľadať. Niektoré achievementy som získal len náhodou, a jeden som musel googliť, aby som mal kompletnú zbierku. Napriek tejto barličke mi neprišlo že by som potreboval radiť. A kto by aj potreboval, tak nech googli, a nájde more youtube tutoriálov.
Preto Ethanovi Dávam Zelenú :)
++grafické podanie prírody
+príbeh, a finále
+náročnosť ak sa to nehrá s tutoriálom - bola to výzva
+ešte raz krásne lesy, prostredie, príroda, jazerá, voda .... všetko uveriteľné, akoby kópia reality
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Pros:

+Gorgeous graphics
+intriguing and well done puzzles with a satisfying result when you complete one
+creepy, beautiful, sad, quite an array of emotional scenes
+A great ending

Cons:

-Short, if you do every scene in the game, you can maybe get about 12 hours
-If you miss something and you reach the end, it will give you a rather vague map of where to go to complete it.  Meaning you could be running for 15 minutes, which for a game that is about the story, is a minor irritation

Conclusion:

An emotional story, great puzzles and overall a very satisfying experience.  The graphics are up there with an ENB-enhanced Skyrim, which is saying a lot.  For $20, I highly recommend it.

Thoughts:

For those wondering why I only have .4 hours logged, I have played and beaten it through, other means (make of that what you will) and after beating it, I went and bought it - this game was a no brainer assuming you have the money.

It seems The Astronauts know that regardless of how good a game is, if the game is only a little over 10 hours, you don't charge $50 or $60, I highly respect this since it shows they know and respect their audience.  I will be watching their next title with anticipation.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is one of the best games I have ever played. If you like atmospheric games, puzzles, story and the fact that you have to think I believe you will enjoy it too.\nIf you want you can play it through and just watch how beautiful it is, enjoy the excellent story and entertaining puzzles. But if you really want to enjoy this game, and take full advantage of what this experience have to offer then take your time and examine everything, get to know the Carter family, their relation to eachother and so on. Remember everything and the ending is excellent. I´d recommend playing with a friend as well so you can talk to eatchother about who is who, what is what and why that is and so on. Play it with your Girl/Boy friend :)

reviewText:
An enigmatic story you have to reconstruct a piece at a time, alone in a small but spectacular world, where, like in a Lovecraft tale, reality, supernatural and oniric dimensions coexist.

reviewText: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a beautiful little mystery game with stunning visuals and a great, lonly atmosphere.  On the surface, you're visiting this remote town in the woods to solve the mystery of what happened to the titular Ethan Carter, but there's far more going on below the surface.\n\nHighly recommended.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is astoundingly alive, foreboding, and immersive. So treacherous and rewarding and beautiful. So poetic and dark and impressive.

This game captivated me.

Withing moments of starting the game I was greeted by a world that felt more alive than any other game I had ever seen. The nature around me seemed to breathe, and the tracks of an abandoned railroad sat, waiting for me to venture to whatever lay at the end.

Basically, I was smacked in the face with a load a' good stuff.

Right off the bat, you are greeted with amazing visuals that blow most games out of the water, wonderful sound design, some mysterious commentary from the narrator (and character you play as) Paul Prospero, and a very bloody dead body on some railroad tracks.

The game introduces some unique gameplay aspects and a disclaimer telling you that it will not hold your hand throughout the mysteries you come across. TVEC stays true to this promise, and as you roam around the dilapidated setting to different locations, you will find that you are only left with your wits- and a nifty power to visualize the memories of dead people once their murder scenes are set up properly.


Pros:
-Astounding graphics, especially for an independant developer
-Gripping, dark story with a Lovecraftian style and a wonderful twist
-Brilliant gameplay. Many well implemented mystery-scene styled features
-Extremely immersive

Cons:
-The models and lip syncing on the characters are a bit stiff, but that doesn't distract too much from the gameplay
-Very short game, only about 5-6 hours of gameplay (unless you're slow like me)
-Some may experience graphical errors (mainly bright red, small, flashing dots in trees) depending on their hardware (the dots were very infrequent for me and did not distract too much, inconvenient nontheless)

The Spooky Pizza's Rating: 9/10

tl;dr- The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a game that will astound you, from its brilliant aesthetics to its mysterious storyline to its engaging gameplay. Worth every penny.

reviewText: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is very much a game about mystery, so I'll keep this brief and suggest you avoid reading too much about the game before playing it (should you wish to do so). It unravels at a measured pace and expects you to figure many things out on your own. So a player who is used to action games is likely to grow bored with it. That said, it offers quite an immersive experience for those who enjoy a slower approach and like to take their time with a game. The presentation is gorgeous and the story is very well told. All in all, I do not regret my purchase.

reviewText:
There are very few times, when people create games with such an engaging story, GREAT atmosphere, incredible graphics, beautiful music score, interesting puzzles and a ♥♥♥♥ing amazing yet oh so saddening twist.

You play as Paul Prospero, a supernatrual detective that investigates supernatrual cases. This time, he has arravied in Red Creek Valley after receiving a letter from Ethan Carter, inspiring him to journey there. Once he arrives tho, he knows that this is a dark place, filled with secrets and mysteries.

Story wise, this game has many tie-ins and symbolisms. Making you really think about the story as you progress and also way after you have beat the game. The way the story is told, makes you intrigued and interested in what will unfold as you progress. The caracthers are diverse and well done, in terms of voice acting and the way they act in general. They feel real and adds several layers to the story. I mentioned that there are also some symoblism in the story. They add these to represent the caracthers throughout the story, that are really neat and well done in that sense that it describes them, symbolically. Which makes you think just how well designed the caracthers and this story is.

This game had me at a very eerie tone for a good portion of the game time, which is great when they can pull something like that off. The lonliness, the darkness and the sadness, it was all just overflowing in the way the music and the noises were done. Making this a headphone-worthy experience, to say the least.

But, does this game have good graphics? For a good amount of the gametime, I found myself on several occasions just screenshotting the sheer beauty of the landscapes. Every detail is well designed  and often breath-taking. There are also NO bugs of whatsoever that I encountered. They maximise the looks of this game to the fullest and it runs pretty damn smoothly. Maybe a lagspike here or there. But who cares, it is not exactly an abselute need for this game to have a perfect framerate. This game is not fast pace, you do not need to have a perfect framerate all the time, though it would add to a better experience with the game I guess.. Oh well.

When it comes to the music, there are mainly two aspects of it. Sadness and darkness, this helps add the tone to the overall experience. Which is something I cannot describe by words, take my word for it when I say: Mikolai Stroinski is a wonderful composer. Take  a listen to Ethan's theme and you will see just how amazing the music in this game can get.

Gameplay-wise there are mainly the search for clues" type of gameplay alongside the "complete the puzzle yourself". This brings me to the next point. You do not get a lot of help in this game
date: however the gameworld is not extremly big
recommended: so this is not that much of an issue. The game also features some horror elements and also 1 horror like sequence (depending on what you refer to as "horror"). I wont lie tho
hoursPlayed: that sequence scared the ♥♥♥♥ outta me.. But the gameplay is nicely done alongside the story and it is at times very creative.\n\nAnd the twist? Well I will not spoil it
voteText: but I will say this: You are not prepared...\n\nIn the end
helpfulPercent: this was an abselute blast of an experience! I loved every single moment of it
votesHelpful:
from the well done story to the fantasticly well composed music to the eerie tone throughout the game. The flaws in this game: none. Well there is one tho.. It ends.

10 outta of ♥♥♥♥ing 10

"One of the best experiences I've ever had in a game""

reviewText:
This game was one I was looking forward to for some time, because it dripped in mystery and that dripping (I should have used a different word) continued throughout the game until the ending. You don't know who you are or what's going on, well YOU being being the player. The character seems to know fleeting reasons for his investigation into where Ethan has gone. But the ending....the ending completely disrupts and erases all elements of the starting point and throughout. I won't say anytmore, to avoid spoilers, but I completed every part of the map and unlocked the ending movie that was suppose to explain everything and it was a flashback scene that had nothing to do with anything that came before. As if we were watching a different show, with the same named characters.

That said, I still reccomend this game, because maybe I missed something out and if you leave the ending scene out, then everything that comes prior is extremely intriguing, curious, slowly evolving as a somewhat cohesive plot but begs to be wrapped up, Was this an homage to Lovecraftian horror or figments of a childs imaginations? I don't know. I'm frustrated now....

The game is beautiful, absolutely breathaking and though you can traverse from start to end quickly enough (once you've completed all the puzzles), the environment feels huge and alive, yet every area is eerie because of the absence of people. You only encounter the residents when you happen upon their corpses and the rest of the time you see ghosts as you use your powers to construct a magical CSI investation.

The astronaut and witch hunt side quests are optional, but cool.

Play the game, but be prepared for a confusion unfufilled ending. I would actually suggest not even activating it. Enjoy the scenery, the puzzles (apart from the maze) and lets see what else the developers come up with.

reviewText: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a strange, yet wonderful beast. The atmosphere is thick and the journey is stunning, but the ending lulls the plot to sleep with an anti-climactic whisper. Or at least, that's how I felt initially. The final scene is something nefarious as it serves to both surprise and confuse the player, raising more questions (amidst a sea of questions) rather than answering some. But the beauty of the ending comes not from what it explains to you, but from what you interpret from it.\n\nAt first, The Vanishing left me with a disappointed feeling--a feeling of, That's it?" And if I had simply walked away and given it no more thought

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW BEFORE YOU PLAY:

This game is beautiful and I like the puzzles, but 2 hours into it I learned I had no clue how to play it and could not figure it out from the options, etc. So here's what I've learned so far about the game mechanics that you need to know before playing (no spoilers):

1. When a word comes up multiple times like a floaty question, slowly look around until all the words overlap to form a single word. It will then flash you into a scene" that shows what you're looking for and it will be in that direction. If you do not do this
date: the item won't appear. I walked past a crank like 7 times without it highlighting because I didn't know about this mechanic. Don't even ask me about the rock. Afterwards
recommended: it's actually pretty cool and makes you feel a little more psychic (plus you can actually play the game the way it's meant without giving up or resorting to walkthroughs).\n\n2. You have an inventory. It doesn't come up. You can't call it up. Things are just pocketed and then pop out when you need them to do something. Therefore you can forget what you're carrying. But don't worry
hoursPlayed: #3. will help with that.\n\n3. When you leave a mystery area
voteText: the thing resets if you didn't complete it. That means things go out of your hidden inventory and back on the ground if you picked something up. Portals come back to their original state
helpfulPercent: etc. So if you want to start the little area over
votesHelpful:
leave and come back.

4. Holding Shift while you move makes you run. Holding Ctrl while you move makes you crouch.

I'm sure there's more. I've only been playing a couple of hours and was totally confused and broke down to see a bit of a walkthrough and realized these mechanics. Back I go to trying it without

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is predominantly a point and click game, reminiscent of Myst and similar titles. It is a captivating, if brief experience that immerses you in a gorgeous world as you attempt to uncover its dark secrets.

First off, the game’s strengths:

The WorldThis game holds some of the best environment visuals I have ever seen. On my journey from plot point to plot point, I would often explore around for no other reason than to take in the views and enjoy the love and care the developers put into every detail. However, the game was very demanding on my computer's resources. On my quad-core i5 with 16GB RAM and Nvidia GTX 680, the game was all but unplayable on high settings due to framerate stutters. With some tweaking, I was able to reasonable smoothness but the framerate still chugged from time to time.

The PuzzlesWhile most point-and-click game puzzles are simply a matter of finding an item X and combining it with location Y to proceed, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter introduces a refreshing take on these mechanics. Most puzzles consist stumbling across a potential crime scene, restoring the scene to its original state, and then deducing the chain of events that led to that outcome. The game offers only a bare minimum amount of hints and does not give the player any instruction on the mechanics of a puzzle or the expected outcome. While this may be a negative for some players, I found I enjoyed solving the puzzles more, as I had to rely only on my reasoning and observations.

The AtmosphereI would not label this game as being a horror title per-se - there is only one jump scare to be found in the game (which is legitimately terrifying!) - but throughout my playthrough, I was surrounded by a constant feeling of dread and suspense. Walking through the game's seemingly abandoned rural setting evoked a great feeling of loneliness and mystery which, when combined with the game's superb score and dark supernatural themes, left me constantly expecting something terrifying to jump out at me or attack me.


And now, some things you might not like:

The WalkingThe game provides you with no guidance on what you are supposed to do or where you are supposed to go and places you in a fairly large open world where it can be easy to miss certain puzzles entirely. Indeed, I missed two or three of the first puzzles entirely and had to backtrack to complete them later. This can be frustrating and time consuming, especially considering the game's minimalistic HUD does not include a map. Fortunately, the game features a sprint option and does include a map/fast-travel system in one section of the game that allows you to jump to any puzzles you might have missed. The game's beautiful environment also helps make this trekking more bearable/enjoyable.

The EndingI found the majority of the game to be very intriguing. The fact that the player knows nothing about the events they are uncovering or even who they are or why they are there really drives the story and draws the player in. However, I found the game's ending to be rather predictable (I saw it coming about halfway through the game) and felt that the twist it tries to pull somewhat falls flat.

Character ModelsThe few characters you see in The Vanishing of Ethan carter appear to be slightly stylized or are, at least, less-detailed/realistic than the rest of the game. This causes their visual appearance to jar with the heavily detailed environment. However, this is a pretty minor nitpick and is easily overlooked.


If you are looking for an atmospheric, narrative experience you can complete in an afternoon or are a fan of mystery, puzzle, or point-and-click adventure games, this title is definitely worth your attention. I enjoyed my playthrough a lot and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it. If you are looking for a longer title with more of a focus on dialog or action or are a gamer with a less-powerful rig, this may not be the game for you.

Από την άλλη, τα μειονεκτήματα που έχει δε κρύβονται κι έχουν με κάνουν με ορισμένες αστοχίες επιλογών, που είναι σε θέση να εκνευρίσουν ή να ξενίσουν τον παίκτη. reviewText:
One of the most visually impressive games around, made even more amazing by a new, remade version with an updated engine and some of the original versions annoyances supposedly ironed out. I haven't played the redux yet, but it comes packed in with the original game for new and past purchasers, which is a very nice move on the developer's part.

With some of the most impressively detailed environments around, the sheer attention to detail alone is astounding. I'd almost recommend this one just for the enjoyment of wandering around looking at stuff, and I'm not the sort who usually cares about graphics. Realistic backgrounds meet strange fantasy elements to make for a very distinct look and feel to things. It really is like playing a dream sometimes.

But prettiness aside, there is also a mystery to be solved here. It's quite a dark one, involving murder, cults, and other things I won't spoil. It all wraps up in a way I found a little unsatisfying, but it's still a compelling narrative to follow. Which is good, because narrative is all he game really has going for it in terms of game stuff. Exploring, some fairly simple puzzle solving, and piecing together the storyline is all there is to keep you busy in the fairly short playtime, but this one's much more compelling than the usual narrative-only games, with some wonderful twists and surprises in store for you as you explore. Not for anyone who wants action, but great at what it sets out to do.

The way the story is told, makes you intrigued and interested in what will unfold as you progress. The caracthers are diverse and well done, in terms of voice acting and the way they act in general. They feel real and adds several layers to the story. I mentioned that there are also some symoblism in the story. They add these to represent the caracthers throughout the story, that are really neat and well done in that sense that it describes them, symbolically. Which makes you think just how well designed the caracthers and this story is.

This game had me at a very eerie tone for a good portion of the game time, which is great when they can pull something like that off. The lonliness, the darkness and the sadness, it was all just overflowing in the way the music and the noises were done. Making this a headphone-worthy experience, to say the least.

But, does this game have good graphics? For a good amount of the gametime, I found myself on several occasions just screenshotting the sheer beauty of the landscapes. Every detail is well designed  and often breath-taking. There are also NO bugs of whatsoever that I encountered. They maximise the looks of this game to the fullest and it runs pretty damn smoothly. Maybe a lagspike here or there. But who cares, it is not exactly an abselute need for this game to have a perfect framerate. This game is not fast pace, you do not need to have a perfect framerate all the time, though it would add to a better experience with the game I guess.. Oh well.

When it comes to the music, there are mainly two aspects of it. Sadness and darkness, this helps add the tone to the overall experience. Which is something I cannot describe by words, take my word for it when I say: Mikolai Stroinski is a wonderful composer. Take  a listen to Ethan's theme and you will see just how amazing the music in this game can get.

Gameplay-wise there are mainly the search for clues" type of gameplay alongside the "complete the puzzle yourself". This brings me to the next point. You do not get a lot of help in this game
date: however the gameworld is not extremly big
recommended: so this is not that much of an issue. The game also features some horror elements and also 1 horror like sequence (depending on what you refer to as "horror"). I wont lie tho
hoursPlayed: that sequence scared the ♥♥♥♥ outta me.. But the gameplay is nicely done alongside the story and it is at times very creative.\n\nAnd the twist? Well I will not spoil it
voteText: but I will say this: You are not prepared...\n\nIn the end

from the well done story to the fantasticly well composed music to the eerie tone throughout the game. The flaws in this game: none. Well there is one tho.. It ends.

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter it's a WEIRD FICTION inspired adventure game, with stunning visual, atmospheric music, non-linear story and gameplay that could leave a mark on every player.

The player has the ability to explore almost every corner of the valley since the beginning, while collecting hints with psychic powers like clairvoyance (clairsentience) and psychometry about the location of a boy who needs the help of the main character and P.I. specialized in supernatural, Paul Prospero.

From beginning to end, the game could be speedrunned quite easily knowing all the location and scenes, and even for the first time some people may finish it with little efforts.
For myself was 4-5 hours of gameplay for the first run, and I was surprised a bit.
Anyway, with its peculiar *not holding hands* gameplay some aspects like story and exploration may be not so obvious for some people so the gameplay time may differ from player to player.

The game itself, if explored and thinked about has more replay value than a lot games in the market, each time you play it, you may find new things and details missed.
Kind of game you wanna show to your friends after you finished it, while giving no spoilers about.
It has 2 parts that are quite a surprise, almost a jump-scare, since the game is quite slow-paced to help the player *breathe the air of the valley*.

About the ending, without spoilers, the game could get off-guard some players. Exploration holds the key for most answers, not all!

A must for Myst-loving players and those who want depth in a game without much help for understanding the *truth*.
Recommended in general for adventure-games fan and for the Lovecraft-lore addict.

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an excellent interactive narrative experience.
First of all, the graphics are absolutely gorgeous and stunning, some of the best visuals I've seen in games. Additionally to that, the soundtrack is amazing and fits perfectly to the mood of the game. Put those together and you get an incredibly immersive game that really sucks you in. And that already makes for 60% of the experience - wandering around in that beautiful world and enjoying the atmosphere is just perfect. You really have to play the game slowly to get the most out of it. (loud headphones and a dark room are helpful, too)

But on to the actual game part. You play as a private detective, who has the ability to communicate with the dead to some degree. He comes to Red Creek Valley after the young boy Ethan Carter sends him a letter asking for help. The purpose of the game is to find out what happened in Red Creek Valley - a place with dark secrets, as you find out quickly. This is done by exploring the area (note here that the game isn't really openworld, but leaves enough room to wander around and explore), finding out the background to murders and solving (mostly easy) riddles. During all that the game does not give you any objectives, there isn't even a real HUD - This game is a narrative experience that does not hold your hand" is a statement that pops up in the beginning of the game
date: and it is 100% accurate. Playtime is around 5 hours
hoursPlayed: but then again the game is no full price title. Still the price could be a bit cheaper.\n\nThis kind of game is special and certainly not for everyone

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is predominantly a point and click game, reminiscent of Myst and similar titles. It is a captivating, if brief experience that immerses you in a gorgeous world as you attempt to uncover its dark secrets.

First off, the game’s strengths:

The WorldThis game holds some of the best environment visuals I have ever seen. On my journey from plot point to plot point, I would often explore around for no other reason than to take in the views and enjoy the love and care the developers put into every detail. However, the game was very demanding on my computer's resources. On my quad-core i5 with 16GB RAM and Nvidia GTX 680, the game was all but unplayable on high settings due to framerate stutters. With some tweaking, I was able to reasonable smoothness but the framerate still chugged from time to time.

The PuzzlesWhile most point-and-click game puzzles are simply a matter of finding an item X and combining it with location Y to proceed, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter introduces a refreshing take on these mechanics. Most puzzles consist stumbling across a potential crime scene, restoring the scene to its original state, and then deducing the chain of events that led to that outcome. The game offers only a bare minimum amount of hints and does not give the player any instruction on the mechanics of a puzzle or the expected outcome. While this may be a negative for some players, I found I enjoyed solving the puzzles more, as I had to rely only on my reasoning and observations.

The AtmosphereI would not label this game as being a horror title per-se - there is only one jump scare to be found in the game (which is legitimately terrifying!) - but throughout my playthrough, I was surrounded by a constant feeling of dread and suspense. Walking through the game's seemingly abandoned rural setting evoked a great feeling of loneliness and mystery which, when combined with the game's superb score and dark supernatural themes, left me constantly expecting something terrifying to jump out at me or attack me.


And now, some things you might not like:

The WalkingThe game provides you with no guidance on what you are supposed to do or where you are supposed to go and places you in a fairly large open world where it can be easy to miss certain puzzles entirely. Indeed, I missed two or three of the first puzzles entirely and had to backtrack to complete them later. This can be frustrating and time consuming, especially considering the game's minimalistic HUD does not include a map. Fortunately, the game features a sprint option and does include a map/fast-travel system in one section of the game that allows you to jump to any puzzles you might have missed. The game's beautiful environment also helps make this trekking more bearable/enjoyable.

The EndingI found the majority of the game to be very intriguing. The fact that the player knows nothing about the events they are uncovering or even who they are or why they are there really drives the story and draws the player in. However, I found the game's ending to be rather predictable (I saw it coming about halfway through the game) and felt that the twist it tries to pull somewhat falls flat.

Character ModelsThe few characters you see in The Vanishing of Ethan carter appear to be slightly stylized or are, at least, less-detailed/realistic than the rest of the game. This causes their visual appearance to jar with the heavily detailed environment. However, this is a pretty minor nitpick and is easily overlooked.


If you are looking for an atmospheric, narrative experience you can complete in an afternoon or are a fan of mystery, puzzle, or point-and-click adventure games, this title is definitely worth your attention. I enjoyed my playthrough a lot and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it. If you are looking for a longer title with more of a focus on dialog or action or are a gamer with a less-powerful rig, this may not be the game for you.

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an immersive, atmospheric murder mystery where you set as Paul Prospero to find (you guessed it!) Ethan. I'll make a simple list here.

- Beautiful graphics
The game is not only treat for your mind but for your eyes as well. You'll find yourselves pausing several times during the course of the game just to admire the sublime scenery.

- Fun gameplay
Like many mystery/detective games, there are no guns. You move in first person with the ability to interact with objects.    The game features different scenes where you have to restore the scene of the crime to correspond to scene of the time of the murder, followed by determining the chronology of the events. Personally, it was a fun and interesting game mechanic.

- Immersive experience
As you go delve deeper and deeper ito the story, you find yourself more and more invested in the story. Also I suggest playing the game with headphones, the background music and ambient sound effects are amazing and you'll feel as if you were truly strolling through a forest  or walking through a mine.

Sidenote: Some people may find $20 to be a bit too much for a little over 4 hours of gameplay but personally, I found it to be more than worth the price.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW BEFORE YOU PLAY:

This game is beautiful and I like the puzzles, but 2 hours into it I learned I had no clue how to play it and could not figure it out from the options, etc. So here's what I've learned so far about the game mechanics that you need to know before playing (no spoilers):

1. When a word comes up multiple times like a floaty question, slowly look around until all the words overlap to form a single word. It will then flash you into a scene" that shows what you're looking for and it will be in that direction. If you do not do this
date: the item won't appear. I walked past a crank like 7 times without it highlighting because I didn't know about this mechanic. Don't even ask me about the rock. Afterwards
recommended: it's actually pretty cool and makes you feel a little more psychic (plus you can actually play the game the way it's meant without giving up or resorting to walkthroughs).\n\n2. You have an inventory. It doesn't come up. You can't call it up. Things are just pocketed and then pop out when you need them to do something. Therefore you can forget what you're carrying. But don't worry
hoursPlayed: #3. will help with that.\n\n3. When you leave a mystery area
voteText: the thing resets if you didn't complete it. That means things go out of your hidden inventory and back on the ground if you picked something up. Portals come back to their original state

leave and come back.

reviewText:
(10/10)

Utterly stunning work.  I really don't know what else to say.  It is an adventure style game, a bit more in the vein of myst than the classic point and click.  The execution though, was flawless and I mean that quite literally.  Every single aspect of what has made games like myst such classics has been executed to utter perfection.

The graphics and sound are beyond immersive and pushing the boundries of what photo realism can achieve on current generation hardware.  The story is suble yet compelling.  The integration of puzzles is perfectly executed as a touch of surrealism that feels completely natural in this world of crumbling structures and abandoned buildings.

Nothing is explained to you, but everything felt completely natural.  I even managed to solve one of the puzzles before I actually got to the 'hint♥♥♥♥♥♥ence' area for it, simply by thinking and proceeding naturally based on the light/shadows/architecture and that was tremenduously satisfying.

The 'user interface' such as it is, is just simple text tracing the thoughts of your character.   Puzzles that would otherwise be potentially punitively frustrating, have built in systems to help you along in a totally natural feeling way... Can't find something? when the text gets a little blurry, look around until you can focus and you can find your way forwards, etc.

In the end though the main 'character' of the game is the world itself.  I could honestly just lose myself wandering through the paths and at times I felt like I already had.  I could swear I've seen bits and pieces of this world in my own life over the years and thats really utterly outstanding.

Normally this is where I would reccomend it to fans of the genre or to people who like x or y.  Honestly though for something of this caliber, its appeal can transcend its genre completely.  Whoever you are, whatever you like, dim the lights, put this game on, and allow yourself to fall into its world and come out amazed.

reviewText:
The world in The Vanishing of Ethan Carter first appears as a beautiful yet sleepy backwoods town, but it quickly becomes apparent that not all is well. A more desolate, abandoned feel grows on Red Creek Valley, like it's been neglected by the outside world for decades, its prime time having long passed. This eerie view of our mundane world is also visible through the documents and newspaper clippings found throughout the valley, portraying an outside view of life in this rural neck of the woods. These external reports are starkly contrasted by Ethan Carter's own imagination, channeling the same goings-on into those of the supernatural, seen in stories scattered across the valley.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter shows an interesting and deep outlook on life—the mundane, sleepy world, against the fantastic imagination of a child. This powerful story combines with a beautiful, polished world together with an immersive music score and great voice acting yielding a top-notch game. But it is what you make of it, as you can beat it in a couple hours if you run from start to finish and skip most of the mysteries, but you will miss out on its deep story. On the other hand, if you explore the whole world and look for all its secrets, puzzles, and mysteries, the game will really shine its brightest.

Another unique and enjoyable part of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is its detective gameplay that reveals pieces of the story with each mystery solved. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is as close as you can get to making a detective novel into a game, and the result is something excellent. The game's succinct yet powerful, thought-provoking dialogue and story tied with its eerie, dark, supernatural premise makes it well worth the time of anyone that enjoys well-crafted mysteries and games with deeper meanings that will stay with players long after finishing.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me say before anything else that I had high hopes for this game. I'm a big reader (and sometimes writer) of weird fiction and I was very excited when they said that it was going to be based around the works of people like Blackwood, Lovecraft and so on. Unfortunately the game itself didn't have a lot of dialogue, had a disjointed story due to the open world design (if you didn't do the puzzles in a very specific order and there were no indicators for that) and that story didn't have a lot of meat to it. And by that I mean it was barely there at all. The game felt empty in the worst possible way a game can feel empty and was very, very, short. The ambiant music didn't fit the theme of the game, but was nice.

On the upside? The developers clearly spent a lot of time making things look absolutely fantastic. If you've got a nice machine this game will make you feel like you're actually walking through the places you explore. I don't have a good computer and even I was kind of wowed by the graphics.

4/10

A good try. Do better next time. You ALMOST had it!

reviewText:
Very beautiful and atmospheric investigation game with a few flaws.
8/10  highly recommend but not at full price, wait for sales (50-60% off)

Positives:
-story
-ambience, music, beautiful scenery
-i did feel the horror element of the game through the whole game without actually fighting anything
(accomplished through music and all the forest sounds, pretty creepy)
-puzzles are interesting enough without being too hard
-love how the world is open to explore and you can backtrack to collect achievements
-enjoyed how they did the reconstruct what happened chronologically with ghosts and it reminded me a lot of Murdered : Soul Suspect

Negatives:
-save system is bad (game saves at predetermined spots which usually overlap with a chapter/mystery being solved)  Then again its not too long so most people will finish it in a sitting or two.
-game is kinda short (around 4h i guess) but it also feels like a natural ending not forced or sped up. Only reason why i do think the game is one to buy on a sale.

Conclusion:
Make more games like these, Really good and ejoyable.

reviewText:
Introduction
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is definitely a thought prevoking game, to say the least. It visually impresses and ensnares with a rather unique take on telling a story in a game. If you don't mind a lot of walking, and maybe even backtracking depending on how you play, the game can be quite enjoyable.

VisualsVisually the game is breath-taking and some screenshots don't really do it all the justice it deserves. From the very get go of the game you will be hit with beautifully encompasing vistas, forests and derelict towns.
The overal attention to design and look of enviroments in the game are really well thought out. You'll be able to feel every bit of tension or emotion emanating from everything from warm exteriors to dark ritualistic crypts.

AudioAgain the game almost overwhelmingly impresses with the audio throughout. The musical score is fitting and flows beautifully between enviroments. Voice acting is also some of the best I've heard; it all sounds natural, clean and no dialog is wasted.

StoryWithout going into any spoilers: go into this game expecting something different, but highly interesting. Your character is in this place looking for Ethan Carter and he's a detective, so it's natural for the story to follow a piece it together" format.
The overal story is very morbid
date: this is made evident from the first few minutes (if not seconds) into the game. Throughout it is basically your job as the player to run around
hoursPlayed: and piece together the overall happenings in this strange little valley  you've entered
voteText: by the use of your psychic powers.\nThis however can run against the games favour though
helpfulPercent: as it's rather core to the overal gameplay.\n\nGameplayFirst off
votesHelpful: just know that many of  gameplay mechanics are actually intricately tied to its story
votesTotal: as that's the games main selling point
votesFunny: its' story.\nAt the start the game could feel a bit overwhelming
commentsCount: as there is truly no hand-holding

column17: hightening the chance for you to actually get the idea around them.\nThere is a lot of walking
column18: but I feel like the addition of actuall content in between segments gives it enough weight to not be considered just another walking simulator. Even dullish walking between segments can very often be broken apart by our detective giving some very well recorded exposition.\n\nThe
column19: "no hand-holding

but mostly just walking and thinking.



Conclusion

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a detective game with some of the hardest puzzles, but will you want to play it ?

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a story driven game made by the ex developers of Bulletstorm. This is a heavy departure from the other games they have made.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter puts you in the shoes of the paranormal detective Paul Prospero. Paul get's a letter from a boy named Ethan Carter who say's something strange is going on at Red Creek Valley and he urges Paul to come here. As soon as we show up we find out something is not right about this place and it's up to us to figure out what happened to Ethan Carter.

Gameplay is really simple. It's a walking simulator, but you actually have to figure out puzzles to figure out what happened to Ethan and his family. This goes from collecting clues to putting together a crime scene to play back a flashback and to find out how that crime was committed.

The soundtrack to this game is phenomenal and the sound effects are amazing too. This game just begs you to play with headphones on. It's a great soundtrack and it's worth purchasing on it's own.

Graphics are absolutely phenomenal. When I first played the game I took some time away from the game just to look around the scenery, it's that good. If you want some nice looking screen savers than this game is surely for you.

Some of the puzzles are insanely difficult as the game doesn't hold your hand from start to finish. It's all up to you to figure out the mystery of the Vanishing of Ethan Carter. You don't take any notes so it's up to you to remember everything you saw and read.

The game took me around 4 to finish and I found it just the right amount of time to complete this game.  Apart from that there's not much replay value. This game is a one time experience. Some of the crime scenes and the ending pack quite a punch and you won't get the same effect the second time through.

I didn't encounter many problems. The only problem I had with the game is a micro stutter when I played through the mine section, but apart from that I encountered zero problems.

Now this is one thing I wanted to address and that's the Ancient Gods puzzle in the mines. This is a spoiler for anyone who will want to play the game so I'll try to keep as less spoilery as possible. You have to find and inspect 4 dead bodies in the mines to get clues so you can open a door. There's a cursed miner that chases you through the entire section and he can kill you in one hit making you restart the entire thing all over again. It took me an entire hour just in that section which annoyed me the living hell out of me. But I guess that's just a rant and not a problem with the game.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a phenomenal experience. I can't recommend the game enough. This game is a must own for any adventure game fan, detective fan and a mystery fan. This game is one of my favorite games of all time and is worth the full asking price. I give The Vanishing of Ethan Carter a 10/10

reviewText: First thing, the game looks awesome!\nWhen I entered it, I was very happy about the freedom you have. No one tells you where to go or what to do. ATIRAXI’S IN-DEPTH THE VANISHING OF ETHAN CARTER REVIEW
SUMMARY
First off I want to express how beautiful this game is; it is one of the best games graphic wise that I’ve seen in a very long time. The game is actually pretty short, only around 6 hours, but the story is excellent for being so short even if it’s just for the little secret stories that are hidden around the game.

I hate scary games with a passion, I can’t play them by myself, just the “horror” tag will drive me away from games the majority of the time. There are a few jump scares in the game, mostly in the very beginning and the middle of the game. The game runs smoothly and has absolutely no glitches at all.

When I was playing and I got to the middle of the game with the jump scare I streamed with someone that already got through the game and they walked me through it so I didn’t have to worry about getting trapped by the jump scare. So if you are worried about getting scared then read a few forums or maybe watch a YouTube video.

PROS
•Excellent story
•Amazing graphics
•Smooth gameplay

CONS
•The game is too short

RATING
8/10
Outstanding atmosphere thanks to gorgeous visuals and music.

reviewText:
Game with stunningly beautiful scenery and small open world, that puts exploration and inquisitiveness to good use (believe me, you'll want to wander around to find all of its secrets and to enjoy the incredible atmosphere). The music also plays big part in its beauty - it is a fitting theme for the unfolding setting and events.

Writing is kept on first glance simple and short, but actually has enough depth and hidden nuances once you delve deeper into it and keep attention to the details. Also a second playthrough puts a lot of it into different pesrpective. Hell, even on the first playthrough you'll soon enough start looking at the things you read or hear in a different light.

Another thing I loved is - the game really doesn't hold your hand, or at least does it minimally. It leaves the setting, story and game-bits unfold in whatever order and pace you choose. But especially if you're the kind to leave no stone unturned - you'll get handsomely rewarded for that.

This game is a truly delightful and amazing experience, I really hope we'll soon see more like it (and similar experiments like Gone Home) breaking the mold.

The game is very short - beat it in ~5 hours, but it is well worth the money.  The scenery and graphics are beautiful.  The puzzles are challenging without being overly difficult.  Everything is very smoothly rendered, even on high.  The atmosphere of the game is spooky without being terrifying and the method of solving each of the puzzles and how clues are pointed out really feel like you're part of the game instead of just guiding someone through it.\n\nI'd give this a 8 out of 10.  The short game play and how it ends only reducing the score a little bit.
Beutiful graphics, intoxicating soundtrack, clever scenario. Whatelse do u need? I wish it was longer but yet..

reviewText: Short answer - Would reccomend, 8.5/10, about 4 hours to play through.\n\nLonger review - Most games like this are not for everyone - short but sweet, atmospheric and spooky but without jump scares like the normal horror fan is used to. However, even if you like games that are action-packed and filled with nothing but cause and effect, taking some time to fall in love with this game will offer you a very rare and special singleplayer experience. Although many other games offer rich story and even more content, this game seems to succeed much more, for me, in capturing you in its Lovecraftian universe. Overall, I certainly reccomend you pick this up if you need a short break from traditional and more popular action based games. Its $20 price tag is well worth the wonderful experience, but you can often catch it on sale if you're low on Steam money. So if you're ready to spend about 4 or so hours to get caught up in the world of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, I reccomend it. Out of 10 I'd give it a solid 8.5, and hope you have just as much fun as I had with this game.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a genuinely chilling mystery/puzzler wrapped in the most beautiful visuals I've ever seen. Despite the generally quiet nature of the game, the narrative kept me on the edge of my seat with an increasing sense of dread settling in as the game progressed, and I found the ending very satisfying.\n\nA gorgeous, creepy, sad, and wonderful experience.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter gets past the trust issues a lot of games seem to have.  The Astronauts have created a world so interesting and beautiful that they're comfortable laying it out before you to discover on your own.  They never tell you what to do, because they know you'll figure it out.  And every discovery you make on your own feels 10x better because you did it yourself.

A magnificent example of how to maintain a great atmosphere and storytelling. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great mystery experience in Red Creek Valley, with dark exploration and devious discovery. The graphics are amazing, and the ongoing view around the mysteries are gorgeous. Unfortunately, the whole game is a bit short mystery, but I enjoyed it all the way through. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoy mystery based puzzles, with an ongoing story which keep surprising and especially if you enjoy one particular early 20th century author.

I can say without a doubt that the Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a refreshing glass of water in this desert of point and click adventure games. At every point I was mesmerized and captivated with the story telling. Not only was this game aesthetically pleasing in every aspect, it made me want to explore every inch of the game.  I will be looking forward to more games in the future from Astro.\n\n

I give it my 9/10 $.

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a short but beautiful story. I wont spoil the story, but I will say that it is hard to follow until the very end of the game. There is no hud or map to guide you through the gameworld, which is a single big forest area. You play as a detective looking for a child by the name of Ethan Carter. The game has no combat.

The graphics are great! (even though it uses the Unreal Engine)
Music is even better and changes dynamicly from scene to scene.

*Spoiler free*

No Hud.
No Inventory.
No difficulty.
No Map.
No Tutorial.
No quests list.
No colectibles.
No acheivments.

Simply put The The vansihing of Ethan Carter is the evolution of the point and click adventure. If you grew up and enjoyed those types of games as i did then prepare yourself for the future.
Firstly, lets get the obvious out of the way, the world is absolutely gorgeous. Indoor, outdoor, lighting all looks amazing. When you see all the grass and trees moving in the wind it is very impressive. I could go on and on about the graphics, but thats just one feature.
I really like how there is a small intro at the start and then it's where do you go, what do you want to do as you walk out of a tunnel. You play as Paul Prospero a pyschic detective who has shown up in the town of Red Rock to find a young fan who has dissappeared. The game is about exploration, and discovery. As you explore about you will come upon bodies who you will then try to piece together how they died. If you are a fan of Sherlock, its basically the same concept of finding the obvious and not so obvious clues and then placing events in chronological order and watching the crime unfold. Its a lot of fun, effective and the most important part, tells a cohesive story.
Without going into story spoliers, after you have completed the game i would suggest going to the deveopers discussion :http://www.theastronauts.com/2014/10/vanishing-ethan-carters-ending-extreme-spoilers/ Super interesting read and will help fill in some holes.
My only dissapointment in the game is the length. I would have liked a few more puzzles but sometimes that is not the answer. The value for me is in the experience and i can easily say it was worth the price of admission.

Positives
Pushes point and click games forward
Graphical powerhouse
Solid story and satisfying ending
The musical score is amazing
Slenderman type level in the mines
Coming out of detective vision back into the color of the world
No hand holding

Negatives
Length
Not fully open world
Sound is minimal and charcter models look bad when you comapre to the amazing enviroments
Exploring off the path is not rewarding. Thought i found a cave off in the woods, on top of a boulder behind a tree, but no access.
Enviromental effects are not utilized. Water dripping in the cave, or rocks falling as an example.

Oh, and be advised - the mechanics may be on the lighter side (you'll never point a reticle at anything), but as the game itself states, this story will not hold your hand; that pondering will be required!\n\nTake your time to explore, read, and ponder the implications along with the beauty of the world.  We did - and the experience didn't disappoint.

Beautiful, mysterious, and ominous.

The Reviewing of...
Ethan Carter is a tough nut to categorise - it's not very long, not very friendly and for the most part, not very interactive. It is however beautiful, atmospheric, and quite interesting while it lasts. Some will call it a 'walking simulator' (as if that is inherently a term of derision), some will call it indie, but me, I'll just call it interesting.

The Breathtaking of...
Ethan Carter is an amazing looking game for such a small studio. Let's just make that clear up front. Basically every moment is a perfect screenshot or video waiting to happen - it's a gorgeously detailed world thanks to their photo-scanning technology. It's a little...austere though, with no wildlife to speak of, and encounters with humans are few and far between. As much as a few birds or butterflies would've enlivened the world though, you only really notice because everything else looks so damn good!

The Playing of...
Ethan Carter is more contemplation than action. For the most part you'll be walking around, taking in the aforementioned beauty, and occasionally solving some light puzzles. In fact there's really only one 'action sequence' in the whole game to my mind; a slightly ill-conceived horror/chase section that aims for tense but trends more toward annoying. Beyond that misstep though, this is a game to be played and enjoyed at your own pace over the course of 3-5 hours. It took me five, but that's because I was looking (craving!) more interactions, collectibles, puzzles or hidden moments than the game actually delivered.

The Summarising of...
Ethan Carter is a solid first effort, displaying impressive visuals and a deft hand at atmosphere from developers The Astronauts. It's biggest fault is really that there isn't more of it - it's a big, beautiful world filled with not very much. And while that's a shame, the discovering of Ethan Carter is well worth your time and money.
My only complaint is that it ended.

Vanishing of Ethan Carter, much like recently released story-driven experiences (eg. Gone Home, Dear Esther, Minervas Den) succeeds in creating a discovery-based story. Robert Frost's The Road Not Taken" may best describe how the puzzles in this game are presented.\n\nThe world is beautiful and if you can run it at full resolution with ultra high details: do so. There were moments where I found myself just wandering and gazing at the landscape. It may still only be polygons and shaders
date: but the amount of detail found in just the juxtaposition of bare faced bedrock along against a subtle man-made pathways made me appreciate the craft of good CG modelling and level design. Things just felt right.\n\nThe Sound design is fantastic. I recommend playing with the music on
recommended: as it creates a great moody cinematic experience. Some may prefer only the ambience of the forest
hoursPlayed: but with a little tweaking
voteText: I found pushing the music back a couple notches and bringing the ambience up helped immensely with the immersion. Also
helpfulPercent: I recommend headphones with this experience.\n\nThere's so many moments in this game where I doubted the intentions of the storyteller
votesHelpful: however
votesTotal: once I realized what I was witnessing
votesFunny: it only empowered my experience.\n\nNo doubt this is a game that for those who enjoyed Gone Home or Dear Esther should play. Definitely worth your time and money :)"

The vanishing of Ethan Carter is a brilliant and beutiful game. If you're in to exploration games with a heavy linear detective stories this game is great. That being said thats what this game comes down to is eploring and being a supernatural detective. The story is good however i was very unsatisfied with the ending, for some reason the ending just didn't do it for me. I really wanted to like the ending since everything leading up to it grabbed my attention (ecluding parts where i had no idea where to go next and the game gives you very little to no direction). The game giving no direction however is something i found very interesting since a friend of mine was also playing through it our experiences were very different espicially since there are some things you could miss or skip over. I'm not sure if those have an effect on the ending or if everything needs to be completed to finish the game (I had already completed everything upon finishing the game) but it reminds me of the stanley parable where two people playing through the game can have tremendously different experiences. This game was great for up untill the ending where i mostly was just wanting more out the ending rather than the ending i got which i found to be very unsatisfying.

There isn't a lot to say about this game that you might not already know, so I'll do what I can. TVEC is a first person story driven narrative with some puzzles tied into the game, you encounter strange things as you travel throughout the world and each of these 'strange things' contributes to an overall understanding to how an individual which resided within the town died. Without going into plot spoilers, I'll say that this game does have twists in a way and the story surprised me. While there aren't that many puzzles and it wont take you more than one seating to beat this game, I do still recommend this game for its 'walk through this town and learn its story' deal and it actually has puzzles and enjoyable gameplay. It's not that long but it's definitely better than Gone Home in my opinion, which I don't consider a game at all.
You'll slowly piece together the mystery of this town, and it will be one worth solving. Just don't expect to be replaying this after you've beaten it, as is the nature of a story driven first person game.

Expected Gameplay w/o walkthrough: 6 Hours
Pros:
- Puzzles are fun, rewarding and give you an understanding of what has happened to the town and its inhabitants.
- The ambient noises coupled with the OST make for a really immersive experience.
- The graphics don't look like terrible and I would say they are actually of AAA quality.
- It actually has gameplay (which is usually the problem with these kinds of games, you kinda just walk through the world and do absolutely nothing as you hear a 2 hour speech).
- The Atmosphere is INSANE!!!!
- Lots of referential stuff to the 20th century, there's even a Lovecraft segment and a space-traveler segment among other things.
(Sort of) Cons:
- Game is quite short, but this isn't a large con, it's worth the money (if it was 80 dollars then it would be a problem).
- The protagonist doesn't talk /that/ much, but this is accounted for by the dialogue exchanges between characters in the 'spirit' sequences where you piece together the mysteries of each section.

General information:
- One difficulty setting
- Saving is done through check-points, not manual so you must accomplish certain things before a save but that's alright because losing progress isn't losing progress at all, if you half solve a puzzle it's not tedious to go through the steps you've already done.
- You may need a decent PC to run this at max settings, there's not a bit of this world that you can see, but can't reach. For the most part there's no like flat backgrounds, because most of the things you can see in the world are actually rendered. On an R9 270X 4GB card, 8GB RAM and a 4 core (3.8GHz) processor I ran this between 60-80 FPS. That being said, it's quite well optimised and I'm sure tweaking the settings to your liking will help with achieving the frame rate you want to. This kind of game can be played in 30 FPS and it will still be immersive.
Overall Rating: 8.5/10
This game is just so beatuiful and it has a good story into it :)

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter will appeal to lovers of old adventure games who are looking for a fresh modern approach to the genre. It is a beautiful game that features a compelling story and some interesting puzzles. Personally I found the puzzles themselves to be fairly simple, but that did not take away from my enjoyment because each one is presented in a unique way. My only complaint would be that this is not a very long game, and while I don't regret paying full price, others may consider the ratio of dollars to gameplay hours to be too low in our 99-cent app store world. In the end, It is my hope that by supporting this game, more like it will follow.

Review Time!!!!       So ill first start out with my original thought of game pre purchase.  I like all sorts of games so long as they bring something to the table that intrigues me.  In this case i had watched the trailer and the gameplay videos on steam, and decided that this game had first off amazing visuals (not just graphically but landscape design was pretty great)  and a style of game play that just struck me as a refreshing change of pace to my growing stack of story driven/puzzle games.  I had discussed the gameplay to my friend, (as we went upon an expedition into the forest to chop trees for quickly arriving winter) then nothing. I guess along the journey I had expressed interest in the purchase of the game, but only whence my financial portfolio was performing better. Fast forward a time we are cutting more wood we arrive back at the casa and i have a steam message.  Turns out whilst i was preoccupied my friend had found time to purchase the game without me knowing, and left me a message  We should play the game upon its download and then something about drinking yada yada  twas a great message.

Game installs we click play and the pre game window launches.  I enjoy when a game does this.  Not only does it remind me about changing the graphics settings, but makes the whole process much easier especially if the game is like Fable Anniversary and has the worst computer interface i have ever had the misfortune of dealing with.  After a few moments of turning everything to  maximum overdrive  it was finally time to play.  The Games Main Menu was very simple nice scenery of a meadow i believe now that i think about it i cant really remember, but i do remember a tree in the bottom left corner. There were four or so options we clicked new game or whatever it is to begin our adventure into saving some small child in a basement from his moth.... oh wait thats the  Binding of Isaac  .... to save a boy whom has vanished.

The game opens into an amazing graphically vivid environment.  Slight nuissance of blurring around the non focused center area of screen, but its an attempt to be more realistic i guess.  Controls are very simple which is good because there is no tutorial.  Straight into  Murder Train  mystery solving.  The solving of events is pretty simple; find dead guy, restore crime scene, and use dead guy's memories (I personally think that Paul Prospero is Dumbledore in disguise hence the use of pensieve) to discover a series of events that you must piece together to gain access to the dead spirits last major memory as its soul is torn from the world of the living.   BOOM  Solved my first scene psychic powers FTW.  Thus far into the game about 15 minutes or so, and the daunting question begins to arrive  How long is this game?"  This question never popped into my mind before

reviewText: A really great narritive.  Come for the gorgeous graphics, stay for the engaging story.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, a narrative adventure game from The Astronauts, is a miracle of game storytelling. It redefines immersion and sets the bar for realistic simulation of the natural world astonishingly high—one could even say, excessively high.

It tells a story about a young boy who appears to have vanished. The gameplay consists of an exploration of his world, uncovering and solving a number of mysteries about what appears to be happening.

The game warns you that it will not be holding your hand, and, through the protagonist, that things are not at all what they seem. The task of the reviewer is impossibly difficult because no explanation of how true this turns out to be can be made without spoiling the experience.

All I will say is this: welcome to the mind of a young boy.

With most games, the game-play is what matters the most. With this kind of game, however, spoiling the story will spoil the game. It is similar to other story driven games like “Papo and Yo,” “Brothers, a Tale of Two Sons,” “Gone Home,” and possibly also the Amnesia games (particularly the second of those). Although the visual style has drawn comparisons to “Dear Esther,” the games are only superficially similar. In The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" one is very much a participant in events.

The game world is breathtakingly lavish and beautiful. For a small game
date: a massive effort at realism has been undertaken
recommended: and it succeeds wildly. If you've seen the game (not just screenshots) than you know that my praise is not excessive. Frankly
hoursPlayed: the story would have stood up well with a far less demanding art style. Yet they brought it off brilliantly.\n\nLike many adventure-story games
voteText: there are puzzles to solve (several of these are quite entertaining and clever; have a pen and paper handy)

votesHelpful: narrative chronologies to determine
votesTotal: locations to discover. The process of uncovering clues and discovering meaning is not difficult
votesFunny: yet the tasks are varied and interesting. The game is not a long one (I stretched it to more than six hours).\n\nHowever
commentsCount: this game integrates game-play and storytelling better than any game I’ve seen. Everything has a reason—even the fact that despite the realism of the world you’re exploring
column16: the sun never moves in the sky. Everything is seamless and utterly engaging.\n\nNone of this would mean anything if it weren’t for the fact that
column17: as the game progressed and the boy’s family situation became more and more clear
column18: I found myself caring about him as if he were my own son. As Prospero the detective

column21: revealed at last
column22:
is moving and satisfying as narrative in a way that few games have achieved. I've read novels that were less satisfying than the story in this game. Think about that a minute.

I’ve got to salute the developer team for performing a miracle: they have created a story that is told in a completely believable world that could not be told in another medium.

The game is not without its flaws

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great example of what a game can be based on nothing but environment and story elements. It uses far-reaching landscapes and beautiful visual effects to bring you a great narrative experience. However, be warned, this game may not be for those of little patience.
__________

Synopsis:

You play as Paul Prospero, who seems to be a detective with paranormal abilities such as ESP. Receiving a letter from Ethan Carter, he learns Ethan has strong psychic connections, and that he has gone missing. Your job is to explore the village of Red Creek Valley and find Ethan. You quickly learn that something is amiss; the town is abandoned, no sign of Ethan's family, and mysterious occurrences.

Story: A short, but interesting tale shrouded in mystery. Perhaps too short, depending on how quickly you progress through the game. It doesn't suffer very much from ups and downs in the story, and it ends pretty well too.

Graphics: One of the most visually appealing games I've played in a long time. A wider, open world gives you plenty of room to stretch your legs and explore, taking in the sights and sounds as you go along.

Functionality: Controls are pretty linear and simple. Essentially a Sherlock Holmes-puzzle solving game. Pick stuff up, find where it goes, and solve problems.

Gameplay: Overall, it's not good. Again, it's basically a point-and-click mystery game akin to Sherlock Holmes. There is no combat mechanics, and every item falls into the one-use category. The real problem I encountered was spending obnoxiously long amounts of time searching the vast landscape for potential clues, which a majority of them felt arbitrary. This is where those of little patience may find the game frustrating.
______________________________

At the end of the day, you're buying this game for the story and the experience; but the experience tends to fall short when you're slowly crawling over a couple acres of land looking for that one last piece of the puzzle. I feel this may have been a better release under a different venue, like Heavy Rain, which offers great atmosphere, narritive, and incorporates at least DECENT gameplay elements.

I did enjoy it, but my advice would be to wait until this game goes on sale to purchase.

Does the outstanding quality of this game justify the higher price? Perhaps, I suppose that's up to the individual player. For me, I would have been much more satisfied with maybe a $15 price.

reviewText:
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a short but beautiful story. I wont spoil the story, but I will say that it is hard to follow until the very end of the game. There is no hud or map to guide you through the gameworld, which is a single big forest area. You play as a detective looking for a child by the name of Ethan Carter. The game has no combat.

The graphics are great! (even though it uses the Unreal Engine)
Music is even better and changes dynamicly from scene to scene.

*Spoiler free*

No Hud.
No Inventory.
No difficulty.
No Map.
No Tutorial.
No quests list.
No colectibles.
No acheivments.

Simply put The The vansihing of Ethan Carter is the evolution of the point and click adventure. If you grew up and enjoyed those types of games as i did then prepare yourself for the future.
Firstly, lets get the obvious out of the way, the world is absolutely gorgeous. Indoor, outdoor, lighting all looks amazing. When you see all the grass and trees moving in the wind it is very impressive. I could go on and on about the graphics, but thats just one feature.
I really like how there is a small intro at the start and then it's where do you go, what do you want to do as you walk out of a tunnel. You play as Paul Prospero a pyschic detective who has shown up in the town of Red Rock to find a young fan who has dissappeared. The game is about exploration, and discovery. As you explore about you will come upon bodies who you will then try to piece together how they died. If you are a fan of Sherlock, its basically the same concept of finding the obvious and not so obvious clues and then placing events in chronological order and watching the crime unfold. Its a lot of fun, effective and the most important part, tells a cohesive story.
Without going into story spoliers, after you have completed the game i would suggest going to the deveopers discussion :http://www.theastronauts.com/2014/10/vanishing-ethan-carters-ending-extreme-spoilers/ Super interesting read and will help fill in some holes.
My only dissapointment in the game is the length. I would have liked a few more puzzles but sometimes that is not the answer. The value for me is in the experience and i can easily say it was worth the price of admission.

Positives
Pushes point and click games forward
Graphical powerhouse
Solid story and satisfying ending
The musical score is amazing
Slenderman type level in the mines
Coming out of detective vision back into the color of the world
No hand holding

Negatives
Length
Not fully open world
Sound is minimal and charcter models look bad when you comapre to the amazing enviroments
Exploring off the path is not rewarding. Thought i found a cave off in the woods, on top of a boulder behind a tree, but no access.
Enviromental effects are not utilized. Water dripping in the cave, or rocks falling as an example.

Oh, and be advised - the mechanics may be on the lighter side (you'll never point a reticle at anything), but as the game itself states, this story will not hold your hand; that pondering will be required!\n\nTake your time to explore, read, and ponder the implications along with the beauty of the world.  We did - and the experience didn't disappoint.

Beautiful, mysterious, and ominous.

The Reviewing of...
Ethan Carter is a tough nut to categorise - it's not very long, not very friendly and for the most part, not very interactive. It is however beautiful, atmospheric, and quite interesting while it lasts. Some will call it a 'walking simulator' (as if that is inherently a term of derision), some will call it indie, but me, I'll just call it interesting.

The Breathtaking of...
Ethan Carter is an amazing looking game for such a small studio. Let's just make that clear up front. Basically every moment is a perfect screenshot or video waiting to happen - it's a gorgeously detailed world thanks to their photo-scanning technology. It's a little...austere though, with no wildlife to speak of, and encounters with humans are few and far between. As much as a few birds or butterflies would've enlivened the world though, you only really notice because everything else looks so damn good!

The Playing of...
Ethan Carter is more contemplation than action. For the most part you'll be walking around, taking in the aforementioned beauty, and occasionally solving some light puzzles. In fact there's really only one 'action sequence' in the whole game to my mind; a slightly ill-conceived horror/chase section that aims for tense but trends more toward annoying. Beyond that misstep though, this is a game to be played and enjoyed at your own pace over the course of 3-5 hours. It took me five, but that's because I was looking (craving!) more interactions, collectibles, puzzles or hidden moments than the game actually delivered.

The Summarising of...
Ethan Carter is a solid first effort, displaying impressive visuals and a deft hand at atmosphere from developers The Astronauts. It's biggest fault is really that there isn't more of it - it's a big, beautiful world filled with not very much. And while that's a shame, the discovering of Ethan Carter is well worth your time and money.
My only complaint is that it ended.

Easily the best game I've played in quite a while. I played through it over two days ago and I still can't stop thinking about it. It takes around four hours to play through which may be a turn-off for some, but the story is so compelling and the graphics are so beautiful that it's hard to put down. The writing is smart and at times intentionally ambiguous, which allows the player to ponder some of the deeper implications of the events presented. The creators seem to be heavily influenced by classic science-fiction and horror literature, and throughout the game pay homage to masters of the macabre like Edgar Allan Poe and H.P. Lovecraft. All of this is presented to the player in a world that is frighteningly beautiful and isolating. The end result is a game that continues to haunt you well after you've completed it.
