Beginning with a pointedly vague premise of your being some kind of detective on the trail of the titular missing child, the game barely holds your hand as you discover your paranormal investigative abilities and begin to piece together a series of strange events in a remote countryside. That lack of hand holding is more a part of the gameplay than one might initially realize as it ultimately provokes a sort of trial and error process that is in itself an investigation. Despite a few fairly simple puzzles, the game is mostly about discovery. While primarily linear, there are various clues and revelations lying just off the beaten path, many of which ultimately need to be discovered to complete the game, but that (whether found later or during the course of your primary investigation) don’t stymie the pace of the game.

The game’s visuals are excellent, featuring not only the river valley vistas seen in the early part of the game, but beautifully dilapidated interiors and dank caves as well. The audio as well is great, with a near perfect score, quality voice acting, and immersive environmental sound. The GUI overlays are brilliant and are realized in such a manner as not feel like an interface, but instead like an extension of the protagonist’s investigative abilities. The ultimate result is a greater sense of immersion and that is a large part of Ethan Carter’s triumph.

Throughout the nearly four hours I spent with The Vanishing of Ethan Carter I was almost completely enraptured by it, spurred on both by a sense of wonderment at the world before my eyes and also by a drive to discover the truth of the mystery at hand. It’s difficult to talk about the story at all without spoiling anything except to say that even when predictable, Ethan Carter delivers with a compelling emotional gravitas. I honestly can’t recommend this game enough to fans of first person adventure games, especially Amenisia, Gone Home, or Dear Esther. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is worth picking up at any price.

The story is not only driven by a quest, but also by the emotion behind it. This makes you want to finish this game in one go. It keeps you hungry for the next part of the story while you are playing it.\n\nI found this game simply brilliant. The only downside is that it has still some issues with certain hardware. This game wouldn't run at all on my MSI GX60 gaming laptop and I'm still experiencing graphics stutter eventhough I have 2 R9-290's inb crossfire.

This is one of those games where the beauty of the atmophere it amazing, but having very little to interact with makes it a bit of a letdown. Some of the puzzles seem to be non-sensical, but overall they're entertaining. There's no jump scares, but the game does a good job of instilling a sense of dread here and there.

The ending is....unexpected. Not in a bad way, though.

I feel that it was worth my time. Recommended.

reviewText: Atmospheric, immersive and clever!
Brilliant game. One of those gems that rarely pop-up in the game market.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, a narrative adventure game from The Astronauts, is a miracle of game storytelling. It redefines immersion and sets the bar for realistic simulation of the natural world astonishingly high—one could even say, excessively high.

It tells a story about a young boy who appears to have vanished. The gameplay consists of an exploration of his world, uncovering and solving a number of mysteries about what appears to be happening.

The game warns you that it will not be holding your hand, and, through the protagonist, that things are not at all what they seem. The task of the reviewer is impossibly difficult because no explanation of how true this turns out to be can be made without spoiling the experience.

All I will say is this: welcome to the mind of a young boy.

With most games, the game-play is what matters the most. With this kind of game, however, spoiling the story will spoil the game. It is similar to other story driven games like “Papo and Yo,” “Brothers, a Tale of Two Sons,” “Gone Home,” and possibly also the Amnesia games (particularly the second of those). Although the visual style has drawn comparisons to “Dear Esther,” the games are only superficially similar. In The Vanishing of Ethan Carter" one is very much a participant in events.

The game world is breathtakingly lavish and beautiful. For a small game
date: a massive effort at realism has been undertaken
recommended: and it succeeds wildly. If you've seen the game (not just screenshots) than you know that my praise is not excessive. Frankly
hoursPlayed: the story would have stood up well with a far less demanding art style. Yet they brought it off brilliantly.\n\nLike many adventure-story games
voteText: there are puzzles to solve (several of these are quite entertaining and clever; have a pen and paper handy)
helpfulPercent: items to locate and put in their proper places
votesHelpful: narrative chronologies to determine
votesTotal: locations to discover. The process of uncovering clues and discovering meaning is not difficult
votesFunny: yet the tasks are varied and interesting. The game is not a long one (I stretched it to more than six hours).\n\nHowever
commentsCount: this game integrates game-play and storytelling better than any game I’ve seen. Everything has a reason—even the fact that despite the realism of the world you’re exploring
column16: the sun never moves in the sky. Everything is seamless and utterly engaging.\n\nNone of this would mean anything if it weren’t for the fact that
column17: as the game progressed and the boy’s family situation became more and more clear
column18: I found myself caring about him as if he were my own son. As Prospero the detective
column19: I became dedicated to finding him
column20: to helping him out of whatever desperate situation he found himself in. And the truth
column21: revealed at last
column22:
is moving and satisfying as narrative in a way that few games have achieved. I've read novels that were less satisfying than the story in this game. Think about that a minute.

I’ve got to salute the developer team for performing a miracle: they have created a story that is told in a completely believable world that could not be told in another medium.

The game is not without its flaws
column23: the principal one being the auto-save system. The game encourages you to explore
column24: and when you uncover the solution to one of the many mysteries
column25: the solved state of that mystery is saved. Each successive “scene” is saved along with the others as you discover them. However
column26: when you quit the game and return later
column27: any scene that you’ve begun but not finished will revert to its “undiscovered” status. This is annoying until you realize what is happening; if you don’t get it quickly—I didn’t—you can potentially lose hours of wandering about. The game is a luscious world that begs you to wander about. Just realize that once you discover a clue
column28: that means (generally) that there are other clues nearby
column29: and that you need to find them all and complete that story segment before you can safely leave the game. It is true that the clues are generally in the same locations
column31: but it helps to be forewarned.\n\nThere are also minor inconsistencies (in the version that I finished
column32: it is possible to have two trains at once in the mine…)
column33: buttons that don’t seem to work properly the first time you press them
column34: and other minor graphic glitches.\n\nBut none of these
column36: which the developer assures us would be impractical to change at this point
column37: detract in the least bit from the game. Once you get into the rhythm of it
column38: and have completed your first scene
column39: things proceed very smoothly.\n\nGamers who liked the games I mentioned earlier
column40: or other story-driven but non-passive games will enjoy “The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.” The art design is best-in-class. The original musical score is haunting and beautiful
column41: and is still playing in my head.\n\nBravo
column42: Astronauts. Thanks for the wonderful story. I’m looking forward to your next project."

reviewText: I love games that involve casual exploration through expansive natural environments, but this game taught me an early lesson that they sometimes hide plot-vital triggers off in the woods. By the end, they will help you find what you missed, but I did not know that at the beginning. For much of the game I was so worried about potentially walking past an investigation point that I could not simply enjoy the wind and the sun setting through the trees. Since the world is very large and interest areas are spread out, it would have been nice to get some sort of audio cue that I was close to one. The developers clearly know about using music to set the mood, it would have been nice to go the next step.

reviewText: Amazing game. The visuals, the story, and the puzzles all draw you into the rich atmosphere. One of the best adventure games I've played in a long time.\nPros: Great graphical quality, good story. Overall well made and practically seamless integration of puzzle and world.\nCons: Don't expect the puzzles to be super difficult. And with a gameplay that runs in a smoothly and challenging way, even not so hard that you may give up.\nI didn't enjoy a game as I have done with this one for years. It is a perfect fusion of story, audiovisual art, and gaming.\nThanks a lot to the team for this jewel.

Spooky, beautiful game. Makes use of mechanics from some of the Sherlock Holmes (although they may be from this game first). The music works really well to give you an idea of how you're progressing, and sets a really nice mood for the game.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a really nice looking and sounding game that takes around 5 hours to finish. Its surreal story is reasonably original and will keep the player interested for the duration of the game.

This type of game requires good immersion to be successful and fortunately it delivers in this regard. Its atmosphere is one of semi-constant uneasiness which will keep you on your toes as you explore its ominous locales.

The main mechanism to advance the story is basically to stumble upon a mystery as you make your way across the setting and solve a few basic puzzles in order to figure out what happened. Said mysteries can be solved in any order.

Some cons of the game are the checkpoint save system and some stuttering issues. Besides these, the game is smooth as a 25 year old Rum Zacapa.

All in all, it's atmospheric and aesthetically pleasing but with some shortcomings, especially its short duration. Give it a go if you like narrative-driven games. Definitely one of the best looking games to date imho.

reviewText: Great game, well worth that 10 or so hours of play. If you like good stories, this one will leave you thinking, Amazing graphics are a bonus.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a beautifuly designed masterpiece.

The very moment you open your eyes, the game absolutely stuns with beautiful visuals and as you are gently walking your first steps in the world, you will immidiately feel that childish sense of wonder and excitement, but that is only the beginning of the beautifu and sad experience that awaits you.

The story is told in a slow pace and you have more than enough time to enjjoy the beautiful scenery. The game is surprisingly not linear yet for most part, you wont find yourself aimlessly wandering. As the story slowly unfolds, you are more and more intrigued by the question how did this happen ?

As you finish the game, the ending will just hit you like a freight train. Absolutely unexpected not even by hardcore book readers / movie fans or gamers.

Even tough I have to say that the storytelling in this game is more subtle and wont get into your bones as much a for example Brothers: Tale of two sons the game makes up for it fully with its stunning visuals, unique game mechanics and beautiful Norwegian like setting.

10/10

I'll get the most obvious thing out of the way first by stating unequivocally that as of the date when this review was written, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is the most gorgeous game in existence. The last time I remember seeing graphics that I almost couldn't believe existed was in the summer of 1997 when they began advertising the pre-rendered FMV cutscenes from Final Fantasy VII. There is - quite frankly - nothing to even compare it to graphically at the moment beyond simple stylistic examples, of which the closest competitor might be Dear Esther.

The soundtrack is very good for setting the vaguely-unsettling mood that drives the plot of the game at a nice, unhurried pace. While none of the tracks are overly thematic - you won't be whistling the bridge song tomorrow afternoon - they're finely crafted and handsomely performed.

The gameplay itself is essentially a walking simulator mixed with an extremely easy point-and-click adventure game; in other words, nothing to write home about but effective nonetheless. Mechanically, the entire purpose of the game is to uphold a beautiful story, a function that is served amazingly well, in part because the mythos itself is so grippingly bizarre in a Cthulhu-like way.

My final verdict is that the game is essentially flawless for what it is and what it set out to be; a great many AAA development studios could learn a thing or two from looking at The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.

While I was venturing through the creepy forests, I was asking myself if it would not be better to leave this whole thing here to a detachment of Marines, but then again, I did feel somewhat responsible to find out what happened to Ethan. Sure, I still preferred to have some Marines with me, but I wasn't even sure anymore if the realm I was in was real, or unreal (oh, btw, game uses Unreal Graphics Engine). I was able to solve the first puzzle regarding a dead guy (CSI style), then, I thought I was too smart for this game, until I reached the next puzzle. Youtube could save my intelligence there a bit, so I was able to solve the problem, thanks to youtube, but I was smart enough to know where to find answers when you need them, so that doesn't make me that stupid.
I am now heck who knows how long into the game, saved a few additional puzzles and all I can say is, to be honest, I have no idea. So let me list the Cons and Pros.
By the way, if you are a COD or BF fanboy, I think this game is nothing for you, you are able to throw a hand grenade into a lake at one point for no reason, that is all about the action you will get up to my point.

Pros:
- You jump up from your chair a few times, scary moments....especially if you are a weakling like me that was too afraid to play Dead Space 2 and other such horror games when being over 30 years of age.
- Graphics if your rig can support max graphics is nearly RL.
- You think of Marines being brought in any second, but it doesn't happen. Game suceeds in adding creepyness.
- You are able to ride a small train over severed legs.
- You feel like being some serious CSI dude after a while.
- You have no idea what the heck is going on, but things start adding themselves together, however, apparently there is still something very, very, very bad awaiting me, it also has a name from a horror movie, I am still hoping Marines to be able to come to help later on in the game.
- You reading this and giving me a LIKE.
- Price: it is good atm for what the game is, truly.
- Good few hours of your lifetime spent.

Cons
- Save system does not exist, just an auto-save that saves after major events like solving a murder case. So play this game ONLY if you know you can spare about 1 hour, otherwise you gota do the whole thing over.
- No Marines so far.
- No weapons unless a hand grenade that you find, if you find it. There was an option for me to throw it into the lake, so I threw it... I hope I was not dumb enough to have wasted the grenade, because the more I play this game, the more I feel like I will be needing that grenade in the end... oh well. They could have at least throw in a pistol with some ammo, would have felt saver at least...
- Space key is useless. You cannot jump in the game. For a gamer that uses since 20 years the space key to jump, that is serious business. I still kept pressing it tho all the time and nothing happened.

So, let's see how this continous, the reason I am writing this is because I just solved another murder case, so finally the auto-save worked (if it did, you do not even see if it did save or not), anyway, gota take a dump now and then walk my dog, yeah just get the game and play it.

reviewText:
Very good experience overall.
It's like travelling without moving.

One of those games everyone should have in their games library.
Brilliant, extraodinary, smashing!\n

This wasn't a fast paced game. It wasn't a first person shooter. This wasn't a fighting game period. This game was a work of art. It told one hell of a story. It is and always will be an incredible game with an amazing story. Period.

This game is a bit of a double edged sword. I'd definitely recommend playing it if you like playing the detective.

However, beautiful graphics and nice, simple gameplay aside; its too short. The game took me around 3.5 hours to complete and that was not rushing through.

I'd recommend getting the game on sale, as it would not be worth full-price"."

Decent immersion, game doesn’t hold your hand yet not so incredibly difficult. Great visuals! Good stuff, would recommend. Kind of wish it left more of a definitive ending but I think it is meant to be left open for interpretation.

Technical:
Doesn't support 21:9 or wider screen resolutions. Flawlesswidescreen fixes this
Built on the Unreal Engine, so performance is amazing and the graphics are breathtaking
Seriously, buy the game, if only to bask in the gloriousness of the PC Master Race

My thoughts:
Masterpiece. Absolutely incredible at building an environment to play in.
Little bit of a learning curve though. This game is a bit...different to play, than any other game I've played before. A lot of weird things go on, that can sometimes creep you out. Don't let your common sense grab hold of you, this is more along the lines of The Twilight Zone.

Think of this title as a supernatural Nancy Drew, the the visual fidelity of Crysis, and the ability to tell a story on the level of Metro 2033.

Stellar game, very much a 'proof of concept though'. Relatively short, you could beat this game in 4 hours if you tried. Although, it does take some getting used to.

My final thoughts on the story of the game: Creations through observation.

(Get it on sale though $10 is a reasonable price point I'd say)

This game was amazing! If you like puzzles that don't hold your hand and just give you the world, this is for you! The world is beautiful, and the puzzles are hard. If you miss anything for a puzzle or scene as the game calls it, it won't stop you. Just later on you will have to redo or complete it. I know that from experience, but luckily it was only one and it was very short. You have to be very opened eyed or explorative to find some of the clues or items. A few had me stuck for a while. The only gripe I had with this game is the save system. If you haven't completed a scene or have gotten a clue it will not save. I had found a work around for this but it was later in the game, when you get on the elevator and move and get off it saves. For example you just get in press up" then "stop" then "down" it will save. All in all I really liked the game and would definitly recommend this game to friends."

reviewText: Highly recommend. Amazing graphics and atmosphere.

Overall it's a good game. The graphics are great looking, and the overall ambience works well. As to the plotline, it's good, but nothing outstanding, it seems to fall a bit flat at the end though. I'd recommend picking it up on sale.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a game that focuses on the narrative much more so than the game play. I'd put it as a close relative to Dear Esther (which I didn't like at all) and Gone Home (which I thought was pretty good). Much of the game is wandering around the absolutely beautiful landscape looking for clues. There are only a small handful of puzzles, but the few substantial ones are very enjoyable. While I was wishing I had more to actually do, the beauty of the presentation, the story and smattering of puzzles made the game worth playing. At 4-6 hours it neither wore out its welcome nor felt too short for the type of game it is. I think if you enjoyed the other two games I mentioned The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is worth a look. Having a little more 'game' to it may also make it worth playing if the thought of wandering around examining things doesn't turn you off too much. As a whole I'm happy with the time I spent with it. My full review can be found  here.[www.oneguytoomanygames.com]

reviewText:
Game with stunningly beautiful scenery and small open world, that puts exploration and inquisitiveness to good use (believe me, you'll want to wander around to find all of its secrets and to enjoy the incredible atmosphere). The music also plays big part in its beauty - it is a fitting theme for the unfolding setting and events.

Writing is kept on first glance simple and short, but actually has enough depth and hidden nuances once you delve deeper into it and keep attention to the details. Also a second playthrough puts a lot of it into different pesrpective. Hell, even on the first playthrough you'll soon enough start looking at the things you read or hear in a different light.

Another thing I loved is - the game really doesn't hold your hand, or at least does it minimally. It leaves the setting, story and game-bits unfold in whatever order and pace you choose. But especially if you're the kind to leave no stone unturned - you'll get handsomely rewarded for that.

This game is a truly delightful and amazing experience, I really hope we'll soon see more like it (and similar experiments like Gone Home) breaking the mold.

The game is very short - beat it in ~5 hours, but it is well worth the money.  The scenery and graphics are beautiful.  The puzzles are challenging without being overly difficult.  Everything is very smoothly rendered, even on high.  The atmosphere of the game is spooky without being terrifying and the method of solving each of the puzzles and how clues are pointed out really feel like you're part of the game instead of just guiding someone through it.\n\nI'd give this a 8 out of 10.  The short game play and how it ends only reducing the score a little bit.
Beutiful graphics, intoxicating soundtrack, clever scenario. Whatelse do u need? I wish it was longer but yet..

(I know, I know, a city is mych different to render than a forest...dont leave stupid comments)\n\nOne thing that amazes me is that so many games are trying to stand out by being open world". Yet

It runs smoother than any game I have yet played. And I can run it at default settings (which are high by default) or even tweak it all the way up on the few options that are set moderately

reviewText: Short answer - Would reccomend, 8.5/10, about 4 hours to play through.\n\nLonger review - Most games like this are not for everyone - short but sweet, atmospheric and spooky but without jump scares like the normal horror fan is used to. However, even if you like games that are action-packed and filled with nothing but cause and effect, taking some time to fall in love with this game will offer you a very rare and special singleplayer experience. Although many other games offer rich story and even more content, this game seems to succeed much more, for me, in capturing you in its Lovecraftian universe. Overall, I certainly reccomend you pick this up if you need a short break from traditional and more popular action based games. Its $20 price tag is well worth the wonderful experience, but you can often catch it on sale if you're low on Steam money. So if you're ready to spend about 4 or so hours to get caught up in the world of The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, I reccomend it. Out of 10 I'd give it a solid 8.5, and hope you have just as much fun as I had with this game.

Great adventure game with a lot of mystery/supernatural feel about it. Very Atmospheric. 9/10.\n\n1st Person View using Unreal engine

This game is absolutely by far the best showcase for the dated Unreal Engine 3, so much so that I still have a hard time believing it really is using it. It really is astonishingly good-looking (honestly, you really have to see it to believe it) with excellent textures and almost photo-realistic landscapes and water and some lovely lighting effects. I was frequently stopping to admire the scenery.

As for the game, it's an interesting variation on concept of walking around exploring (like Dear Esther or Gone Home) but with some nifty puzzles that once completed reveal more of the story. Unfortunately, if the game has any faults it is that the lack of any kind of hand-holding or tutorials at the start led me to being confused as to what I was actually supposed to be doing. And because the game is not linear and I was exploring rather than solving the puzzles then I found that my progress was not being saved (the game only saved on completion of puzzles rather than at specific points on the map, though this may have changed now with newer patches).

Despite that, which may not be an issue for others, this is a very unusual, beautiful and relaxing game to play so it is hard not to recommend it.
Atmospheric and engaging.

Fantastic game. Visually striking, interesting gameplay and good story. Only about 3 hours long, but I thoroughly enjoyed it and would recommend to anyone who likes adventure/puzzle games.

It can be good to have a friend who has completed the game that can give you a nudge here or there but without spoiling anything.

So to begin with I picked this game up for £6 on sale.

This game has beautiful Music & Graphics, right from the word go.  You can roam freely and explore and gather clues at your own pace. There is no hand holding so at somepoints it will require a little bit fo thinking in order to progress the story, But that shouldn't put people off, no degree is needed.  Exploring and getting deeper into the story you will find the hours just slip away, you can very easily melt into this game.

Would i Recommend this game to someone? yes. but only if they like puzzle / mystery games with good ambience and immersion.

Would I buy this game at full price... ermm Yes

My favorite author is H.P. Lovecraft, so I make a point of checking out every game or movie that claims to be inspired by his work.  Usually the end result is pretty weak sauce, but sometimes I find epic experiences like Eternal Darkness or Dark Corners of the Earth ... or shorter, but still powerful stories like Ethan Carter.

The game's story is more in line with Lovecraft's early work, with the focus on internalized existential angst with a smattering of references to the wider mythos and the power of dreams.  It's a slower, more personal, self-contained story, rather than one about ancient aliens rising up from terrible slumber to end humanity, which is fine.

Gameplay is all about investigating a series of murders in the gorgeously rendered Red Creek Valley while searching for Ethan Carter.  There is no combat and no way to die (although there is a gamebreaking bug that I at first mistook for character death towards the end, if you solve one of the puzzles before the final murder, that requires you to close the game and continue from the previous save).

The unique method of sensing the psychic residue of strong emotions and reconstructing the timelines of the murders is clever and provides the only real action" to what is primarily a short story you get to walk through and witness.  There are no outcomes to change

reviewText:
This game is absolutely by far the best showcase for the dated Unreal Engine 3, so much so that I still have a hard time believing it really is using it. It really is astonishingly good-looking (honestly, you really have to see it to believe it) with excellent textures and almost photo-realistic landscapes and water and some lovely lighting effects. I was frequently stopping to admire the scenery.

As for the game, it's an interesting variation on concept of walking around exploring (like Dear Esther or Gone Home) but with some nifty puzzles that once completed reveal more of the story. Unfortunately, if the game has any faults it is that the lack of any kind of hand-holding or tutorials at the start led me to being confused as to what I was actually supposed to be doing. And because the game is not linear and I was exploring rather than solving the puzzles then I found that my progress was not being saved (the game only saved on completion of puzzles rather than at specific points on the map, though this may have changed now with newer patches).

Despite that, which may not be an issue for others, this is a very unusual, beautiful and relaxing game to play so it is hard not to recommend it.

a superb atmospheric experience with very beautiful graphics (even if the polygon count is not quite perfect yet, I give it 5 years until the graphic cards will be able to render a photorealistic world).\n\nexcept for the jump scare in 1 of the puzzles in the mine (where I had to take off my headphones for a while), the game made me feel warmer at the soul wherever I walked by
Excellent laid back game that has a pretty dark twisted story to it.

This game is awesome. It's like playing through an old scary story along the lines of Algernon Blackwood or H.P. Lovecraft, with some investigation gameplay that is among the best crime scene gameplay I've ever seen and which matches the mood and atmosphere of the setting. Due to their method of using interpolated photographs of real objects to make a lot of the 3D models, the game looks much better than other current gen games that have the same technical level of graphics but which use the standard method of 3d modeling. The game looks much more photorealistic than any other I've played, and it helps the mysterious atmosphere a lot. The story, atmosphere, and gameplay all go together extremely well and make for a great experience.

At my age of 33 I consider myself an adult gamer. So consider this as you read this review. I finished the game in approx. 5 hours - and I was amazed from the beginning to the very end. The tasks you have to perform to develop the story are simple but entertaining. They game feels and plays much like an interactive movie and the graphics are beautiful. I probably won't play it ever again because it has zero replay value but it was worth every penny I spent on it. If you are going to purchase this keep in mind that it is for relaxation and does not offer action (imho)
Great looking game, interesting story, happy I bought it! Just wished it was longer. Looking forward to similar games from this developer. Nice work!
beautiful landscape, a story that unfolds as you play, and a great ending, all the things that make a good game and this game has them all.

AS long you know what you are getting, this is pretty neat.  It's meant to be a slow exploration of a forested area full of nooks and crannies.  Some mild puzzle elements (and one hella annoying maze section).  The story is appropriately spooky and ends well.  Just don't expect the second coming of adventure games.  At most, it's a decent mood piece that lasts about 2-3 hours.

Only fault of this game was it's shortness. It took me 6 hours to go through it without any helps, and I did many mistakes or didnt know where to go. But that 6 hours was totally rock'n'roll from the very start to the bitter. Totally worth to buy and please do so.

I almost didn't buy this game because of the negative reviews it has gotten, but I am so glad I did!

First off...there is no hand holding in this game. Which sucks at first when you are confused and don't know what the f**k is going on but you can figure the game out pretty quick and I think the lack of hand holding is nice. It allows you...or makes you...enjoy the setting by wandering around and exploring.

The story is amazing!

The ending....OMG. I still can't get over it.

The bad thing about this game is the saving. It saves after you accomplish something and shows up in small writing at the top of the screen. It was annoying at first when I wanted to stop playing but couldn't because I didn't know when it last saved. Also my PC kept crashing ( because it does that, not because of the game) so I had to replay some things, but honestly it doesn't take that long to redo something. And once you trigger an elevator...going up or down it triggers an auto save.

Some people say this game has not replay value and I would argue that it does and does't. It's all depnds on the person, I personally feel it has a good replay value, espeacially if you wanted to do a speed run or something.

I would recomend buying this game...but not at full price. I paid $9 for it so it was well worth it. I'd say even $15 is worth it.

Buy it. Play it. Love it. Regret nothing.

In Brief
Somewhere between walk-'em-up and adventure game, The Vanishing of Ethan Carter blends the best elements of both.

Most valuable resource:  The atmosphere.
Of interest to: people who like their walk-'em-ups with just a tad more gameplay.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter received a lot of buzz in the indie-sphere, and rightly so.  It also has its detractors, and I can understand why.  There is just enough game here for it to be unequivocally a game, unlike other narrative-driven walking simulators like Dear Esther and Gone Home and thus, like Eidolon - another gamified stroller - Ethan Carter left itself open to criticism focusing only on the game elements.

Now don't get me wrong, the game elements here are brilliant.  You are a supernatural investigator who stumbles across murder victims, hunts for clues using your psychic sense, assembles them, then gets to see little still poses of the victim and their murderer assembled around the scene.  By tagging them in the correct chronological order, you get to view a cutscene that explains what happened.  This denouement is masterfully done.  The process of stumbling across and then piecing together all the elements of the crime is entertaining, and doesn't break your immersion in the tense atmosphere the game is building by forcing you to involve yourself in mindless tasks or fiddly interfaces.

But while these murders drive the narrative, the crime scene investigation definitely plays second fiddle to you just walking around this town.  I think the balance is just right, but for those who like more game in their game, the short running time combined with the few instances of this interesting mechanic equals not much game.  And I think that's a real shame, because the beauty of this game is in the way it artfully places you in a plausible scenario dealing with increasingly implausible elements that all have such gravity because the scene, the mood, the atmosphere are all so engrossing and so foreboding.

The one criticism I do have is that that one wonderful mechanic is not explained.  It is barely referenced that you have this extra sense, and how your window on the past expands by assembling clues is never mentioned at all.  It doesn't help that the very first scene you encounter, the one where your powers are introduced, is completely atypical, lacking a body or any clues to assemble, and using a different visual to literally every other instance of the sense that occurs the entire duration of the game.  As far as communicating mechanics organically through gameplay goes, that's a cardinal sin.  I feel like the developers have heard this complaint before, and have inserted a warning up-front that the game does not hand-hold as a defence against this criticism, but if you find your players are googling ethan carter touch not working" so frequently that google autocompletes the search three words in you've not communicated well enough.  And that's a real shame
date: because having to backtrack to redo the puzzles you didn't realise were puzzles kinda breaks the flow of the narrative and takes you out of the game.\n\nI do want to especially call out the jump scare section.  Ethan Carter is that rarest of beasts: a horror(-ish) game with an effective and appropriate jump scare.  Half way through the game
recommended: when the tension has been built and you're starting to get a sense that these are more than just mundane murders

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a genuinely chilling mystery/puzzler wrapped in the most beautiful visuals I've ever seen. Despite the generally quiet nature of the game, the narrative kept me on the edge of my seat with an increasing sense of dread settling in as the game progressed, and I found the ending very satisfying.\n\nA gorgeous, creepy, sad, and wonderful experience.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter gets past the trust issues a lot of games seem to have.  The Astronauts have created a world so interesting and beautiful that they're comfortable laying it out before you to discover on your own.  They never tell you what to do, because they know you'll figure it out.  And every discovery you make on your own feels 10x better because you did it yourself.

A magnificent example of how to maintain a great atmosphere and storytelling. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great mystery experience in Red Creek Valley, with dark exploration and devious discovery. The graphics are amazing, and the ongoing view around the mysteries are gorgeous. Unfortunately, the whole game is a bit short mystery, but I enjoyed it all the way through. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoy mystery based puzzles, with an ongoing story which keep surprising and especially if you enjoy one particular early 20th century author.

I can say without a doubt that the Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a refreshing glass of water in this desert of point and click adventure games. At every point I was mesmerized and captivated with the story telling. Not only was this game aesthetically pleasing in every aspect, it made me want to explore every inch of the game.  I will be looking forward to more games in the future from Astro.\n\n

Great game, beautifully written and presented. The breath-taking graphics and storyline really stays with you even after completing the game. Highly recommended.

A mixture of Dear Esther and Gone Home.

The story is revealed to you bit by bit as you explore the world as in Gone Home. But in my opinion the story is really good, in contrast with Gone Home that is somewhat basic. It can be hard to make the player engaged in the exploration of a rich story and not get lost in it's complexity in the middle of the game, but this game just makes it perfect.

Actually, the word perfect, describes the game well. Everything in it is perfect. The story, the setting of the abandoned village in the middle of mountains, the soundtrack, the voice casting, the technological visual marvel, the game mechanics to solve the mysteries, the mood.

The only downside that I can see in the game, is the lack of save functionality. The game has auto-save in certain key-points, normally after completing a sub-story. For one side, I didn't get frustrated by it, since the mood and involvement the game creates, you just want to keep playing it. But it can be troublesome if for some reason you need the stop playing and you are in the middle of something.

Hope to see more games like this. Maybe it revitalize the genre of point-click adventure games, following this game steps.

reviewText: Loved this game, it just throws you right in, and lets you work out what to do.\n\nThe game draws you in right from the start, good narrative, gorgeous looking game world, only wish it was longer, but would love to see more games like this!

One the best narratives in a game. It's not a game that holds your hand every step of the way, which is something the developers warn you as soon as you start playing.\n\nAlso, the game is absolutely gorgeous. Some really breathtaking scenery.

Not a long game but very beautiful with a gorgeous soundtrack.  Quite linear, you will find that you can only interact with very specific objects and items which lessened my enjoyment somewhat as the details were beautiful but only there to look at most of the time.  I wanted to open old cupboards and drawers and satisfy my voyeuristic curiosity but that's not what this game is about.  The ending was quite fascinating.  Lovely game overall.  Very enjoyable.
Great visuals, entertaining (but mostly simple) puzzles, and a great soundtrack.
Very atmospheric game, creepy in places yet with a good story I found very engaging. Some really nice aspects of the game mechanics used to tell events and stories. Very good game.

Not five minutes into this game, I had already taken at least twelve screenshots. The beauty of this game is striking and is something that will be mentioned in countless other reviews. Even though it may only take about 4-5 hours to finish, you may end up taking much longer than that because every few seconds you'd want to stop and stare at the scenery. Just make sure you don't spam your activity feed with screenshots of the whole game. No doubt you would be tempted to.

Props must also be given to the sound in this game. Ambient sounds combined with brilliantly written music create the perfect atmosphere. They complement the environment making you feel wonder, awe or even terror.

Apart from looking gorgeous, Ethan Carter tells a story that is very well written. As you progress through the game you will encounter puzzles of varying difficulty and upon solving them you uncover pieces of the story. Even though some aspects of Ethan's tale will no doubt be confusing (I was scratching my head at many scenes) it remains engaging throughout, leaving you itching to know what happens next.

There are a few small issues I had with the game, nothing major. This is just me nitpicking. It is a very short game and the puzzles are not aplenty. Most of them I was able to solve easily. Only one or two required some serious thought. Nonetheless, they were all fun to do.

At full price, Ethan Carter is $20. I paid half of that in the Winter Sale and it found it to be a great buy for what I paid. It's up to you if you want to pay full price for this very short indie title (Ignore the 30hrs I have clocked on Steam, I had gone out and forgot to exit the game) but if you do, I doubt you would regret it.
Deliciously moody and atmospheric, with originality, and a puzzle format that doesn't become old. My only complaint is that it I wish it lasted much longer. Well worth the modest price.
I bought this game just for the visuals and got an amazing story. This game is a most-play!!!

Beautiful. I did not realize how good this game looked when I bought it. It's well optimized and it runs flawless on my pc.

I finished the game the same day I bought it. I don't regret this purchase one bit. You are an occult investigator who received a letter from a boy asking for help. You begin the game when you arrive. Entire game is first person and well written. The voice acting is decent as well.

You seem to have some psychic abilities of your own and you use them to help solve puzzles and figure out what the hell happened to the boy and his family, and why everybody is killing each other. Nice little twist at the end. There's puzzles where you try to figure out how murders happened to ethans family and many others. They aren't too difficult either.

This is an exploration-puzzle kind of game. Not for everyone. If you think it is something you would enjoy, just buy it. It is a very good game and worth your money.

Its not clear on the steam store page that it works on windows 7, just to confirm it does work on window 7 64 bit.\n\nA very interesting game, there is a video explaining how to put the clues together on the steam store page which helped, and there are YouTube walkthroughs which helped me to obtain some clarity in some areas.

Love this game! I'd give ot 9 out of 10.\nThe reason I didnt give it 10 is because the characters were not particularly well made or animated for a modern game.\nOther than that tiny issue, this game is perfect.

You should know what you're getting into here. It's a game based on story and exploration. No action, minimal puzzles. As long as that doesn't completely put you off the whole idea, then definitely give this a try. It's eerie, subtle horror at its finest- no jump scares, no looming theat (except for one very brief, easy to beat segment). And yet the game left me deeply chilled, and more than a little bit sad.\n\nBut if you play, have a guide on hand. Not because the puzzles are hard (they're not), but because some things are easy to miss- and you have to solve every puzzle in order to complete the game. If you don't want to spend an hour backtracking to that one spot you missed, check the guide every so often to make sure you haven't skipped anything. No need to read ahead or spoil things for yourself- just read up to the point you reached and see if there's anything you should have done.

This game is gorgeous!!!  The textures and design are nothing short of delicious.  The story is really engaging and kept me and my SO hooked start to finish.  We are Myst junkies so we love puzzles and mystery.  We spent a solid hour just scowering the forrest for pieces of something that wasn't there.

I guess the only sad thing about this game is it really is quite easy complete.  The puzzles usually solve themselves, or have the answer somewhere near by.  In the Myst series we were used to searching everywhere for clues to the answer for the next puzzle.  Not necessary in this game.

INCLUDING the hour spent in the forrest we beat this game in one afternoon (4 hours).  Which was pretty disapointing.
We only spent $8 on sale so it really didn't offend us, the visuals and the way they played out the story was absolutely worth it.

TLDR; GREAT GAME - EASY - DEDICATE AND AFTERNOON AND GO START 2 FINISH

TVEC is an extraordinarily immersive game that succeeds by providing the player a fascinating abandoned world to explore. The landscape and buildings seem to be of a time and place one can't easily pin down, though the setting is somewhere in the modern day USA. I was reminded of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. by lonely hills, forests, and tunnels that may or may not be haunted. The supernatural exploration detective game Betrayer comes to mind as well as the paranormal investigator protagonist combs the terrain for clues.\nThe story is hit or miss. I had a hard time buying into the story, but I was familiar with the type of tale being told. The incorporation of certain horror literature elements were rather well done but it was the interpersonal family dynamics that weren't as convincing as they could have been. The twist" ending (depending on your point of view) wasn't very profound and the idea of ghosts "letting go" alternately fascinates and bores me. It was done reasonably well in Betrayer

Incredible, breathtaking visuals enabled by creative use of photogrammetry and loving, meticulous artistic work. The amount of effort that went into crafting every meter of the world here is unmatched even by the best triple-A teams working on budgets orders of magnitude bigger. This is a masterpiece in environment art, an example to study. I definitely recommend reading the development blogs of the project for the look into the process - lots of developers should learn from this game.

This carefully crafted environment is not there to be a passive eye candy either - it's an irreplaceable tool for telling the story. It sets the mood, manipulates your expectations and carefully directs your progression through the story.

I'm not really sure what can be done to improve the game, actually. It's a complete, well-executed, focused product. There is no need for more action, the peaceful walks at your own pace are the definitive way to go through the experience - there is no place for explosions, crowds or thrilling chases here. There is no need for bigger environment - you don't need rock climbing, wing suits, boats and additional ten kilometers of lush forest to tell this story. There is no need for weapons, for inventory, for HUD.

The sound work deserves high praise too - the environment is brought to life through masterful use of ambient, and the music is brilliant. So yeah, can definitely recommend this. Even if you prefer more active genres, this is a game is worth supporting - it represents the work attitude, fascination with art and understanding of narratives that I would love to see more in the game development industry.

Let's start off with the good side of things.

The graphics, in short, are the best you can witness at this point in time. It is really a stunning looking game. I'm really surprised I can't actually smell the environment through my screen because it looks so beautiful. 10/10 - This really sets a bar, and simply needs to be experienced to be believed.

Sound design is also exceptional. All the music and other auditory cues are timed very well and create a good atmosphere. I do feel that a lot of games get this right, though. Having played other games where atmosphere is important, I think developers realize that you just can't build a good immersive game without the proper auditory cues. This game makes great use of its music, sound effects, and just absolute, dead silence whenever necessary. It creates a very eerie atmosphere indeed.

The story is very intriguing itself. It's got a nice, Bioshock level twist at the end. I do have to say that I expected this game to be a bit more focused on the horror" aspect

reviewText: I quite liked it, it was an interesting experience with really good narrative.

“Vanishing of Ethan Carter” is a beautiful work of art. There are so many details to find and theories to craft that each player will get an experience of his own. The game mechanics are all solid enough to hold the game together and keep you interested through the whole journey. Sound and world design can compete with AAA titles, yet alone put many of them to shame. But the pacing and openness of the world also dictate your speed. The overall experience may last between 3-5h, and your mileage can vary greatly depending on your capability to find the important areas soon enough without getting frustrated.

But having finally reached the end you will feel a bit like an astronaut. You explored something completely new, and your experience, paths chosen and memories taken were your own. For me that is a clear characteristic of a great game.

Read the full review here and look at tons of good screenshots[metadragon.de]
BLAZED/10

The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter is a newly released mystery themed first person narration developed by indie developer The Astronauts. Though this is the first release by the newly formed developer they are built up of very experienced developers and The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter certainly passes off that vibe. The game plays out with you, Paul Prospero, walking throughout the small village of Red Creek Valley. The core of the game consists of you going through the town solving each murder mystery that the town has to offer, which is quite a few for such a small place. Since the core of the game is it’s story, I’m going to write this review without going into details on the story, so rest assured this review will remain spoiler free.

So like I said the game plays out as a first person mystery solver. The game begins with the text “This game is a narrative experience that does not hold your hand” and that is about the most definitive statement I can say about this game. The game is totally open world and will not give you any guides or hints about where to go or what to do. This is nice in the sense that you are totally free to explore the world and solve mysteries as you stumble upon them. As you explore you’ll notice items that seem to be missing from scenes. As you explore the world you’ll often find the missing items scattered around so that you can investigate and pick up the items. When you finish putting a scene back together you are able to open a portal into another dimension to explore and discover the secrets of what happened in the world. Exploring the story was interesting and though it felt like a good bit of the story didn’t quite fit in at the time of discovery, after further exploring and really examining the environments the pieces all came together. The story is really the reason to play the game. Their really isn’t much action, and you will spend almost all of your time exploring, examining and then walking to your next location.

Luckily walking around the game world means you get to view more of the environments. The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter has possibly the best graphics I’ve ever seen in a video game. I mean the world is truly astonishing and is incredibly realistic. There were a number of times I actually had to stop playing, to admire the fact that what I was staring at was not a real life picture. And with the exception of one location, a mine, all were very unique yet realistic in their design. Not to say that the mine wasn’t well designed, but compared to the rest of the world the rocky maze like mine just seemed rather boring. The titles sound effects were not nearly as well done as the games graphics but quite honestly I found myself so indulged in the visuals of the game that I very rarely focused on the sound effects.

Finally the ending of the game is one that I really enjoyed. The ending doesn’t explicitly say what happens one way or another. This works especially well because The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter leaves the story open to certain speculations. The end is left for you to sit, think about the events of the game and determine how it ends. Additionally the amount of small details you’ve paid attention to can actually have great effects on how you interpret things which can ultimately lead to an alternate view on the ending than you would have had otherwise. Unfortunately The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter is very short at roughly four to five hours to complete and because of the way the story plays out replay value is limited.

8/10

PROS
• The best visuals seen in recent years
• Small details that can effect the way you see the ending
• Very well done open ended ending

CONS
• Story is only about 4-5 hours length
• The design of the mine level

The game is worth full price, but I've often seen it on sale. I reckon it is only good for one proper playthrough then the story is told and the plot revealed. The world's visual glory might cloud the story but the unadorned gameplay steers narration with a clear focus and little regard to the player's ability to trail it. Pieces don't fall in place until the end, and the outcome might leave the player emotionally unrewarded. Nonetheless it compresses the game's themes into a satisfying whole.\n\nThe story's hopefulness is its love letter to literature. It's the celebration of imagination and the naivistic nod to those who have tried to escape desolation in a dysfunctional family. It's the absence of absolute evil; Sleeper's function is not to frighten, it is to reflect our innermost needs.

This game is a hardcore mystery/puzzle game not for the faint at heart but if you do play the game you will see it has some of the best visuals ever for a game. It is truly eye candy. The PC version is built on the Unreal 3 engine and the PS4 version is built on the Unreal 4 engine. There will be an update coming for PC that will update to the U4 engine soon. I can only imagine what the game will look like when this happens. Until then I have stop playing the game and will continue when the changes have been made.

This mysterious first-person adventure game is a beautiful and bizarre experience that I enjoyed very much once I wrapped my head around the style of gameplay.  The player moves through an enormous world while investigating unknown events that occured there, gradually revealing a story in chunks at a time.

Even as soon as the first scene loads, it becomes apparent that the game does not plan on helping you figure much out.  The story progresses only when you manage to figure out certain nondescript sequences of events that are required to move the game forward. There are no loading screens, and you are left to wander in a quiet forest and valley of intimidating size and detail until you figure it out.  This is not a miserable thing, however, because the graphics are fantastic, the sound effects are incredibly lifelike, and the score is perfectly fitting.  When the realization hits you that you've figured out exactly what the devil that one critical action does that you've been hung up on for so long (and when it actually helps), you can progress with relative ease.  Once you learn to speak the language of its concepts, the game becomes much more enjoyable.  Dare I say it reminds me of  Myst  because of that? Again, not a miserable thing despite the possible implications.

The graphics and game engine really are astounding.  The forest areas are so realistic in composition to real life, it's like the developers took a photo somewhere in the most picturesque forest known to man and animated every minute detail of it.  Not only that, the architectural design of the buildings and props is astute as well.  If one can find flaw in this game, it is most likely not going to be in the visuals.

The story itself is very interesting and clever once you get used to its delivery.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter  is well worth the experience.  It is consistently interesting and engaging throughout even when you are not sure what needs to happen.  This game deserves the praise it gets.

A fantastic game by a small development team. The gameplay is fairly simple but some of the puzzles will give you a nice bit to chew on. Should give you about 3-6 hours to play through if you don't use a walkthrough, so be warned that it's a short, self-contained experience.

But what an experience that is. This game's atmosphere is excellent, ranging from mystifying to creepy as you explore the derelict ruins and secluded countryside. The game's environmental graphics, ambient sound effects, and haunting soundtrack round off an excellent presentation that will likely remain unrivalled for quite some time. The character models and animations are a bit standard-fare and, while not bad, stand out as average when compared to the rest. The voice acting is fairly good, especially from the main character, whose voice provides occasional narration to the story.

If you've ever wondered what would happen if you blended some Twin Peaks and a little bit of Silent Hill and had an occult investigator serve as the protagonist, and then poured it into a nice cup of game: this game is for you.

Wow. This game was such a fun experience! The Narrative gameplay really works out well and the puzzles are challenging without being impossible to complete. Most of all, exploring the world is a pure enjoyment. As you discover new elements of the story, and mystery, you feel an urge to continue and find out even more.\nIt took me a while to finally pick it up, but I'm so glad I did. Everyone should experience The Vanishing of Ethan Carter.

A breath of fresh air to what I usually play, this game is beautiful to look at and I found myself wanting to explore every nook and cranny within Red Creek Valley (I did a rhyme!). While it could have been a longer experience, the story climaxed into an ending that is open to the players interpretation which was quite cool. Found it pretty creepy in some parts too and the soundtrack is very atmospheric (and also creepy).
Perfect Graphics\nVery Good atmosphere

reviewText: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is an extremely beautiful mystery game. I found myself applying a lot of thought while working through the puzzles and exploration in this game. To fully experience The Vanishing of Ethan Carter you need to pay attention to every cutscene and every clue that you come across. Don't use tutorials. The satisfaction that you get after completing a puzzle is what makes this game so rewarding. The graphics are stunning and the open world is seemlessly constructed. The story is truly amazing and it leaves you to decide how you want to interpret it. This game requires patience. I 100% reccommend the Vanishing of Ethan Carter to anybody looking for a challenging puzzle game.

reviewText: The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a cerebral adventure-mystery that'll keep you hooked until you finish it. Like fo' real. That's what I did. Great music, great visuals, and an engrossing story. If you like story-heavy games and puzzle/mystery games that don't hold your hand, you'll enjoy this!

If you loved Myst, you need to buy this game.

If you ever restrained yourself from looking up the solution to a puzzle because you were enjoying the game so much that you didn't want it to end sooner, you need to buy this game.

If you loved the game Painkiller, you need to buy this game.

If you've ever read a book so engaging it painted worlds with beauty beyond imagination, you need to buy this game.

If you appreciate fine art, you need to buy this game.

If you're a programmer or engineer and love to see things well done, you need to buy this game.

If none of the above applies, buy this game to support the brilliant devs and then go read a book or two.

Up front: This game is very short - exepect to finish it in four hours or less unless you somehow miss one of the puzzles and have to backtrack. It offers no real replay value - while the story is presented in a non-linear manner where the only puzzle you need to complete before the others is all the puzzles before the last one, there is no variation. Only one solution for any given puzzle, and all puzzles must be completed to finish, leading to a sense of guide dangit if you bypass one of the early ones, which could be easy to do if you weren't coming the land. If you can tolerate a short and linear game for a vivid experience, I'd recommend it.

That is the only major complaint I have with the game - the plot is very good with an excellent ending, the narrator is pleasing to listen to ( although not as good as a Bastion ), the environments are fairly detailed with a sprinkling of places you can't enter as part of the plot railroad. The soundtrack is great, and the sound work is just as good. The graphics, while not the best in the world, are very well done and sell the setting.

The main puzzles are fairly simple, but interesting - you will be attempting to solve murders of people and must track down each clue before you enter a timeline where the events must be placed in the correct order ( which can lead to some guesswork as not all are clear until you get it wrong the first time ). The side missions are more varied - you chase an astronaut and go into space, you must navigate a house where all the doorways have portals in them, making them line up correctly to reach the wizard's protected room, and a few others.

If the developers were to release a TellTale-type chapters game following the mentioned but unelaborated previous cases of the player, Paul Prospero, I'd be all over that in a heartbeat, but the experience itself is worth a few bucks - certainly as much as you'd pay for a visual novel or light book - but not quite 10 dollars - once it reaches the 5 dollar mark it becomes worth it.

the story overall was great but also terrible, in my opinion the ending could have been done in a much more elegant way than what it was which kinda ruined it for me.

in one of the missions you are faced with a puzzle to open the door... look up the combination online because other than receiving the first and last numbers you need to solve it, it gives you no help in putting the next 4 together, so logically if you did it properly because there are 6 combinations, it would take 81 attempts to get the combination correct, which in my opinion is completely stupid and something the developers definitely messed up on. although having the first and last combination told to you, the way they showed what other numbers you had to put in, they should have shown in order or give a hint in which the order should be done.

Incredibly stunning graphically, this is a neat little murder mystery adventure game. The game takes place in one huge map and you can get sidetracked wandering around. reviewText: I don't usually write reviews on games, but I thought I needed to write one for this one.\nEven though the game is short (I finished it in 5.5 hours) I would most definitely recommend getting it if it's on sale. There is never a time limit or any enemies that kill you, all you have to worry about is solving them. My biggest mistake is rushing through the game from the beginning. If you take your time and look around the world, you will have a better gaming experience. This game is definitely worth playing.

Let's get a few things out of the way first. I'm not sure whether to recommend this game or not, but I can recognise the developers created something extraordinary here, and that at least deserved being mentioned.

This game is basically a walking simulator, but unlike for example The Stanley Parable, there are no alternate routes or endings. Replayability is non-existent here. Depending on how leisurely you play and how fast you resort to walkthroughs, you'll get about two to five hours out of this 'game'. In that sense you're probably thinking this game is overpriced, and I agree.

I won't go into too much detail about the story, as that really is the meat of the game. I don't want to take away from that. But essentially, you are Paul Prospero, a detective with a keen eye for the supernatural, and you have come to Red Creek Valley per request of Ethan Carter's fanmail. As you solve murders and puzzles, the overarching plot reveals itself to you through cutscenes and voice-overs.

The way this works is you are dropped into a gorgeous, sprawling open-world with the clues scattered about. This is very reminiscent of point-and-click games, but the difference is you can actually (un)intentionally skip puzzles or scenes and walk further into the world. But to get the ending, you'll have to eventually solve every puzzle.

To summarize

Top-notch visuals and music score make for a very eerie atmosphere. Easily the best part about the game.
Absolutely zero replayability. Best when played through in a single sitting in my opinion. Try keeping a spoiler-free walkthrough handy if you don't like the idea of wandering aimlessly until you bump into a clue.
The plot is alright to excellent, depending on your personal taste, but I don't think anyone can call it poor.

If you like games such as The Stanley Parable, Dear Esther, or are otherwise interested in video games as an art, definitely pick this up if you catch it on sale. I can best summarize this game as being dropped into a gorgeous but gloomy lovecraftian film which you can explore and walk around in.

That all being said, it's definitely not for everyone. I personally see this game for all its worth but it's hard to 'recommend' it in the typical sense.

This game creeps and puts you on edge without anything campy or over the top. The game does a great job developing an unease, making the player feel as if they are a tresspasser in a land where things just are not quite right. The graphics and sound are beautiful bringing to life ancient forests, dilapidated structures, and artifacts of industry gone by the wayside. I really enjoyed wandering the map.\n\nWhich you will have to, because there isn't a lot that is intuitive about The Vanishing of Ethan Carter." Players who enjoyed the old "Myst" series will find some nostalgia here

reviewText: A narrative without hand holding indeed.  I thought this one was well worth the $12 during the Steam holiday sale.  It took me about five hours to see it all, which included some wandering where I was just stuck but not enough to be frustrating.  The game actually did a really good job ending one mystery in the general vicinity of the next, so that you weren't completely lost but also didn't receive any flashing arrows.  I like that the over-arching story makes you think and doesn't even give away exactly what happened.  There is some room for interpretation.

The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a great story game. The story is small in scope but great and well-polished.
No hand holding here you can do any puzzle which order you want but not doing them will get you lost in the story and its charters.
Buy it for a good story with amazing graphics and beautiful music

Deeply immersive and throughout mysterious narrative experience from the eyes of Paul Prospero - a detective, who's not afraid of descending into the darkest abyss to face the inside and leave no unanswered questions...

Okey, so where do I begin with this game, First off the graphic's are utterly amazing and it was a very beautiful game, there isn't many controls so they were very easily picked up and you are on your way solving the the clues left in the game. this is where it gets complicated, although you don't have to do everything in order, it would certainly helped if it did, because you may find yourself (like i did) running back and fore throughout the game trying to solve things i've missed to get futher into the storyline...

the story overall was great but also terrible, in my opinion the ending could have been done in a much more elegant way than what it was which kinda ruined it for me.









SPOILER AHEAD --------






in one of the missions you are faced with a puzzle to open the door... look up the combination online because other than receiving the first and last numbers you need to solve it, it gives you no help in putting the next 4 together, so logically if you did it properly because there are 6 combinations, it would take 81 attempts to get the combination correct, which in my opinion is completely stupid and something the developers definitely messed up on. although having the first and last combination told to you, the way they showed what other numbers you had to put in, they should have shown in order or give a hint in which the order should be done.
Very funny game, the best part was when all the stuff happened.

TVEC is an extraordinarily immersive game that succeeds by providing the player a fascinating abandoned world to explore. The landscape and buildings seem to be of a time and place one can't easily pin down, though the setting is somewhere in the modern day USA. I was reminded of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. by lonely hills, forests, and tunnels that may or may not be haunted. The supernatural exploration detective game Betrayer comes to mind as well as the paranormal investigator protagonist combs the terrain for clues.\nThe story is hit or miss. I had a hard time buying into the story, but I was familiar with the type of tale being told. The incorporation of certain horror literature elements were rather well done but it was the interpersonal family dynamics that weren't as convincing as they could have been. The twist" ending (depending on your point of view) wasn't very profound and the idea of ghosts "letting go" alternately fascinates and bores me. It was done reasonably well in Betrayer

This game is amazing.

Great mechanisms for finding clues and re-creating murder scenes. Incredible graphics. Perfect soundtrack.

The voice acting is a little clunky here and there. And it's way too short.  I finished the whole thing in about three hours. Unfortunately there is little to no replay value.

Only because of the short play time, I can't recommend this game at full price.  But, if you see it on sale, you should pick it up.  I paid $12 and I feel like I got my money's worth.  If they came out at $10 buck a pop, I'd probably buy a dozen games like this.

Note: I actually played the Redux version.  But for some reason I can't write a review for that version.  Therefore, I logged into the basic version for 15 minutes to unlock the ability to review here.

This game is definitely worth the money you pay for it. It has a wonderful, if not short, story filled with creepy vibes, strange twist and heavy cult-like symbolisms throughout the game. The Vanishing of Ethan Carter takes a wonderful approach to story telling wherein the protagonist, Paul Prospero, looks for 'clues'  to solve puzzles related to the Carter family and their ties to this strange place known as Red Creek Valley. By the end of it all, you'll be asking yourself what just happened and trying to go back and understand just how this tragic event for the Carter family came to pass. If there's one game to try this holiday season, this is it.

This game won me with incredibile photorealistic landscapes and mature writing. First time i played, even if i new that this  was a narrative game inspired from one of my favorite horror writers (Lovecraft), i still got the chills in the vast world of Reed Creek Valley near those beatiful abandoned landmarks, prepared for something to happen. I recommend this game for all who love a good story, exploration and want to get lost in a beautiful land.

The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter is a newly released mystery themed first person narration developed by indie developer The Astronauts. Though this is the first release by the newly formed developer they are built up of very experienced developers and The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter certainly passes off that vibe. The game plays out with you, Paul Prospero, walking throughout the small village of Red Creek Valley. The core of the game consists of you going through the town solving each murder mystery that the town has to offer, which is quite a few for such a small place. Since the core of the game is it’s story, I’m going to write this review without going into details on the story, so rest assured this review will remain spoiler free.

So like I said the game plays out as a first person mystery solver. The game begins with the text “This game is a narrative experience that does not hold your hand” and that is about the most definitive statement I can say about this game. The game is totally open world and will not give you any guides or hints about where to go or what to do. This is nice in the sense that you are totally free to explore the world and solve mysteries as you stumble upon them. As you explore you’ll notice items that seem to be missing from scenes. As you explore the world you’ll often find the missing items scattered around so that you can investigate and pick up the items. When you finish putting a scene back together you are able to open a portal into another dimension to explore and discover the secrets of what happened in the world. Exploring the story was interesting and though it felt like a good bit of the story didn’t quite fit in at the time of discovery, after further exploring and really examining the environments the pieces all came together. The story is really the reason to play the game. Their really isn’t much action, and you will spend almost all of your time exploring, examining and then walking to your next location.

Luckily walking around the game world means you get to view more of the environments. The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter has possibly the best graphics I’ve ever seen in a video game. I mean the world is truly astonishing and is incredibly realistic. There were a number of times I actually had to stop playing, to admire the fact that what I was staring at was not a real life picture. And with the exception of one location, a mine, all were very unique yet realistic in their design. Not to say that the mine wasn’t well designed, but compared to the rest of the world the rocky maze like mine just seemed rather boring. The titles sound effects were not nearly as well done as the games graphics but quite honestly I found myself so indulged in the visuals of the game that I very rarely focused on the sound effects.

Finally the ending of the game is one that I really enjoyed. The ending doesn’t explicitly say what happens one way or another. This works especially well because The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter leaves the story open to certain speculations. The end is left for you to sit, think about the events of the game and determine how it ends. Additionally the amount of small details you’ve paid attention to can actually have great effects on how you interpret things which can ultimately lead to an alternate view on the ending than you would have had otherwise. Unfortunately The Vanishing Of Ethan Carter is very short at roughly four to five hours to complete and because of the way the story plays out replay value is limited.

8/10

PROS
• The best visuals seen in recent years
• Small details that can effect the way you see the ending
• Very well done open ended ending

CONS
• Story is only about 4-5 hours length
• The design of the mine level

reviewText:
A true narrative experience.
Refreshingly different.
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter brings you to a beautifully rendered environment filled with mysteries and murder.
At around 4 hours long it is the perfect play length for an afternoon, although you might want to watch playing at night.
If you enjoy good story-telling, great visuals, and any sort of mystery novel, this one's for you.
(Everything else would just be spoilers)

An absolutely enthralling experience to start to finish.\nThe graphics are stunning (if your computer can handle it) and help set the mood of the narrative.\nThis is one of the best experiences from a game I've had. It will make you feel things you didn't expect to fall into. Regardless of how long this is, it's a definite must-have. Pick it up on sale and enjoy!
